      2.   The wilful making of any false statement as to a material fact in
application for a license.
      3.   Permitting any illegal, disorderly or immoral practices upon
licensed premises.
      4.   Violation of any of the provisions of the United States treasury
department relating to the possession and sale of intoxicating liquor or the
laws of the United States relating to the same.
   C.   Period Of Suspension: The period for which a license may be suspended
under this section shall be, for the first offense, not less than ten (10) nor
more than thirty (30) days; for the second offense, not less than fifteen (15)
nor more than forty five (45) days; and for the third and each subsequent
offense, not less than thirty (30) days nor more than sixty (60) days. (Ord.
78-12, 7-5-1978)
   D.   Period Of Revocation: Where a license is revoked under this chapter, no
new license shall be issued on the licensed premises for a period of at least
twelve (12) months thereafter. (Ord. 78-12, 7-5-1978; amd. Ord. 93-13, 12-1-
1993)
3-2-23: APPEALS:
An appeal of an order of action of the local liquor control commissioner, being
timely filed, shall be limited to a review of the official record of the
proceedings of the commissioner. A certified official record of the
proceedings, as taken and prepared by a certified court reporter or certified
shorthand reporter, shall be filed by the commissioner within five (5) days
after notice of the filing of such appeal to the Illinois state liquor control
commission. Such certified official record shall be the sole evidence presented
in the review before the Illinois liquor control commission and shall serve in
lieu of a trial de novo. (Ord. 93-13, 12-1-1993)
3-2-24: PENALTIES:
Any person who violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon
conviction, be punishable by a fine as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed
committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. (Ord.
78-12, 7-5-1978; amd. Ord. 93-13, 12-1-1993; 2013 Code)
ARTICLE A. BYOB ESTABLISHMENTS
SECTION:
3-2A-1: Statute Authority
3-2A-2: Licenses Required; Fee
3-2A-3: Ineligibility For License
3-2A-4: Application For License
3-2A-5: Insurance Required (Rep. by Ord. 2017-24, 8-9-2017)
3-2A-6: Investigation Of Applicant; Approval Or Disapproval
3-2A-7: Number Of Licenses
3-2A-8: Term Of License; Proration Of Fee
3-2A-9: Change Of Location
3-2A-10: Transfer Of License
3-2A-11: Renewal Of License
3-2A-12: License To Be Posted; Duplicates
3-2A-13: Days And Hours Of Operation
3-2A-14: Vacated And Forfeited Premises
3-2A-15: Sanitary Premises
3-2A-16: Corking
3-2A-17: Suspension Or Revocation Of License
3-2A-18: Penalty
3-2A-1: STATUTE AUTHORITY:
This article is adopted pursuant to the authority of 65 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/11-42-10.1 allowing the license of a business operating as a public
accommodation. (Ord. 2009-10, 4-8-2009)
3-2A-2: LICENSES REQUIRED; FEE:
No person shall allow the consumption of alcoholic beverages in his
establishment without having first obtained a license so to do as provided by
this article and paid to the Village Clerk the license fee for such license,
which license shall be designated and classified as provided in this article.
The license fee for a BYOB license shall be three hundred fifty dollars
($350.00) per year, payable in advance on an annual basis. (Ord. 2017-19, 7-12-
2017)
3-2A-3: INELIGIBILITY FOR LICENSE:
No license shall be issued to:
   A.   A person who is not of good character and reputation in the community
in which he resides.
   B.   A person who is not a citizen of the United States.
   C.   A person who has been convicted of a felony under any Federal law or
the laws of the State.
   D.   A person who has been convicted of pandering or other crime or
misdemeanor opposed to decency and morality.
   E.   A person whose license issued under this article has been revoked for
cause.
   F.   A person who at the time of application for renewal of any license
issued hereunder would not be eligible for a license upon a first application.
   G.   A copartnership, unless all of the members of such copartnership shall
be qualified to obtain a license.
   H.   A corporation, if any officer, manager or director thereof, or any
stockholder or stockholders owning in the aggregate more than five percent (5%)
of the stock of such corporation, would not be eligible to receive a license
hereunder for any reason other than citizenship and residence within a
political subdivision.
   I.   A corporation unless it is incorporated in Illinois, or unless it is a
foreign corporation which is qualified under the Illinois Business Corporation
Act to transact business in Illinois.
   J.   A person whose place of business is conducted by a manager or agent
unless said manager or agent possesses the same qualifications required by the
licensee.
   K.   A person who does not own the premises for which a license is sought,
or does not have a lease thereon for the full period for which the license is
to be issued. (Ord. 2009-10, 4-8-2009)
3-2A-4: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Application for BYOB license shall be made to the Village President in writing
upon a form prepared and furnished by the Village, signed: a) by the applicant,
if an individual; or b) by at least two (2) members of a partnership, if the
applicant is a partnership; or c) by the president and secretary thereof if the
applicant is a corporation, and verified by oath or affidavit of the signers.
The application shall contain the following information and statements:
   A.   The name, age and address of the applicant in the case of an
individual; in the case of a copartnership, the persons entitled to share in
the profits thereof; and in the case of a corporation, for profit, or a club,
the date of the incorporation, the object for which it was organized, the names
and addresses of the officers and directors, and if a majority interest of the
stock of such corporation is owned by one person or his nominees, the name and
address of such person.
   B.   The citizenship of the applicant, his place of birth and if a
naturalized citizen, the time and place of his naturalization.
   C.   The character of business of the applicant; and in case of a
corporation, the objects for which it was formed.
   D.   The length of time that applicant has been in business of that
character; or in the case of a corporation, the date on which its charter was
issued.
   E.   The location and description of the premises or place of business which
is to be operated under such license, and the name of the owner of the premises
if not owned by the applicant and the date of the termination of the lease held
by the applicant. If leased, a written permission statement from the owner is
required to be attached to the application.
   F.   A statement whether applicant has made similar application for a
similar or other license on premises other than described in this application.
   G.   A statement that applicant has never been convicted of a felony and is
not disqualified to receive a license by reason of any matter or thing
contained in this article or in statute.
   H.   Whether a previous license by any state or subdivision thereof or by
the Federal government has been revoked, and the reason therefor.
   I.   The date of incorporation if an Illinois corporation, or the date of
becoming qualified under the Illinois Business Corporation Act to transact
business in Illinois if a foreign corporation.
   J.   A statement that the applicant will not violate any of the laws of the
State of Illinois or of the United States or any ordinance of the Village in
the conduct of his business.
   K.   That the applicant is willing to show satisfactory proof of good moral
character and reputation. (Ord. 2009-10, 4-8-2009)
3-2A-5: INSURANCE REQUIRED:
(Rep. by Ord. 2017-24, 8-9-2017)
3-2A-6: INVESTIGATION OF APPLICANT; APPROVAL OR DISAPPROVAL:
The President of the Board of Trustees shall investigate the statements in each
application, and the character of the applicant and, within thirty (30) days
after any such application is referred to him, shall recommend or report in
writing the rejection or approval of such application. Such report or
recommendation shall be filed with the Village Clerk and be referred to the
Board of Trustees at its next regular or special meeting. Any rejection so made
by the President of the Board of Trustees shall be final, and no license shall
be granted by the Board of Trustees if rejected. (Ord. 2009-10, 4-8-2009)
3-2A-7: NUMBER OF LICENSES:
The number of licenses to be issued shall be three (3). (Ord. 2009-10, 4-8-
2009)
3-2A-8: TERM OF LICENSE; PRORATION OF FEE:
All licenses shall be for the term of one year and shall expire on June 30
following their issue. For every license issued on or after January 1 of any
calendar year, the license fee shall be one-half (1/2) of the annual amount
specified, but there shall be no further fractional division of license fees
payable under this article. (Ord. 2009-10, 4-8-2009; amd. 2013 Code)
3-2A-9: CHANGE OF LOCATION:
A license as defined herein shall permit the possession of alcoholic liquor
only in the premises described in the application and license. Such location
may be changed only upon the written permit to make such change issued by the
Village President. (Ord. 2009-10, 4-8-2009)
3-2A-10: TRANSFER OF LICENSE:
A license shall be a purely personal privilege, good for not to exceed one year
after issuance unless sooner revoked. Any such license shall not be
transferable except upon written application and approval of the Village
President. (Ord. 2009-10, 4-8-2009)
3-2A-11: RENEWAL OF LICENSE:
   A.   Applications for renewals of licenses shall be filed with the Village
Clerk on or before June 1 of the calendar year. (Ord. 2009-10, 4-8-2009; amd.
2013 Code)
   B.   The Village Clerk shall report the names of all applicants for renewals
of licenses to the Board of Trustees at its next regular meeting and shall
present the signed application of the applicant, the amount of license fee
payable or tendered and whether or not any written complaint has been filed as
to the manner in which the applicant for such renewal of a license has carried
on the business authorized thereby.
   C.   All applications for renewal of licenses shall be referred to the
President of the Board of Trustees for recommendation as to rejection or
approval as in the case of applications for original licenses, and the
procedure upon such recommendation shall be as in the case of applicants for
original licenses.
   D.   An application for renewal of any license upon its expiration shall not
be granted if written complaint has been filed with the Village Clerk or
President of the Village Board of Trustees as to the manner in which the
applicant for such renewal has carried on the business authorized by such
license until hearing has been had on such complaint. The President of the
Board of Trustees shall act on the approval or rejection of such application
for renewal within five (5) days after the completion of the hearing on said
complaint. (Ord. 2009-10, 4-8-2009)
3-2A-12: LICENSE TO BE POSTED; DUPLICATES:
Every person licensed in accordance with the provisions of this article shall,
immediately upon receiving such license, post and keep posted, while in force,
in a conspicuous place on the licensed premises the license so issued. Whenever
such license shall be lost or destroyed, a duplicate in lieu thereof shall be
issued by the Village Clerk upon the payment of a fee of ten dollars ($10.00).
(Ord. 2009-10, 4-8-2009)
3-2A-13: DAYS AND HOURS OF OPERATION:
No person issued a license under this article shall permit his or her
establishment to be opened for the possession of such liquors between the hours
of one o'clock (1:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. of any day, except on
Sunday mornings when such establishment may remain open for the possession of
such liquors until two o'clock (2:00) A.M. (Ord. 2009-10, 4-8-2009)
3-2A-14: VACATED AND FORFEITED PREMISES:
The premises for which a license has been issued shall be operated as a going
business, and in the event said premises is closed for more than ninety (90)
days without specific prior authorization from the Village President, the said
license issued to said premises shall be declared vacated and forfeited. (Ord.
2009-10, 4-8-2009)
3-2A-15: SANITARY PREMISES:
All premises licensed under this article shall be kept in a sanitary condition
and shall be open to inspection by the Village President, Chief of Police or
any other authorized official of the Village. (Ord. 2009-10, 4-8-2009)
3-2A-16: CORKING:
The applicant must provide for the recorking of opened liquor and the resealing
of such in State approved tamperproof bags/containers. No alcoholic beverages
may be stored or kept on the premises during non-business hours. (Ord. 2009-10,
4-8-2009; amd. Ord. 2017-24, 8-9-2017)
3-2A-17: SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
   A.   Authority: The President of the Village Board or his duly authorized
representative shall investigate any violation of this article, the making of
false statements in any application for license or the permitting of any
illegal, disorderly or immoral practices upon licensed premises and may suspend
or revoke the license covering such premises if, upon completion of a hearing,
the facts warrant such revocation.
   B.   Grounds For Suspension Or Revocation: Any license issued under this
article may be suspended or revoked for any one or more of the following
reasons:
      1.   Violation of the laws of the State or of any of the provisions of
this article.
      2.   The wilful making of any false statement as to a material fact in
application for a license.
      3.   Permitting any illegal, disorderly or immoral practices upon
licensed premises.
   C.   Period Of Suspension: The period for which a license may be suspended
under this section shall be, for the first offense, not less than ten (10) nor
more than thirty (30) days; for the second offense, not less than fifteen (15)
nor more than forty five (45) days; and for the third and each subsequent
offense, not less than thirty (30) days nor more than sixty (60) days. (Ord.
2009-10, 4-8-2009)
3-2A-18: PENALTY:
Any person who violates any of the provisions of this article shall, upon
conviction, be punishable by a fine of not less than twenty five dollars
($25.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense,
and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which
a violation occurs or continues. (Ord. 2009-10, 4-8-2009; amd. 2013 Code)
CHAPTER 3
AMUSEMENTS
SECTION:
3-3-1: Definitions
3-3-2: License And Compliance Required
3-3-3: Application For License; Investigation
3-3-4: License Fee
3-3-5: Liability Insurance
3-3-6: Term Of License; Nontransferability
3-3-7: License And Capacity To Be Posted
3-3-8: Persons On Duty
3-3-9: Conduct Of Business
3-3-10: Prohibited Acts And Conditions
3-3-11: Requirements For Specific Amusement Establishments
3-3-12: Additional Requirements
3-3-13: Revocation Or Suspension Of License
3-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and terms shall have the
meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section:
BILLIARD CENTER: A place of amusement or entertainment in which one or more
persons are invited to play and participate in the game of billiards, including
pocket table billiards or snooker table billiards, or wherein one or more pool
tables or billiard tables are kept, used or operated for profit or in the
course of a business enterprise.
BOWLING ALLEY: A place of amusement or entertainment in which one or more
persons are invited to play and participate in the game of bowling or wherein
one or more bowling lanes are used or operated for profit or in the course of a
business enterprise.
GAME ROOM: A place of amusement or entertainment in which three (3) or more
mechanical amusement devices are kept or maintained for the use of the public,
operated for a profit or in the course of a business enterprise.
MECHANICAL AMUSEMENT DEVICE: Any musical device, pinball machine, novelty
machine, skill machine, pool machine, bowling machine or similar machine which
operates or may be operated for use as a game of skill, amusement or play and
for which a charge is made, whether coin operated, token operated, ticket
operated, time operated, operated by control of an operator or operated as an
enticement for the business enterprise.
OPERATOR: Any person, firm or corporation who keeps or allows billiard or pool
tables to be kept on premises owned by him or under his control where the same
may be played by members of the public legally upon such premises upon payment
of the charge therefor.
OWNER: Any person, firm or corporation who owns and places billiard or pool
tables by whatever arrangements on the operator's premises.
PUBLIC SKATING RINK: Any room, place or space in which skating, either on
roller skates or ice skates, is carried on and to which admission can be had by
the public by payment, either directly or indirectly, of a fee, or by payment
of a charge for any service auxiliary to skating, or by purchase, possession or
presentation of a ticket or token; but the term "skating" shall not be held to
apply to exhibitions or performances in which the persons paying for admission
do not participate.
THEATER: Any room, place or space for the showing of motion pictures, plays,
musicals, concerts or other entertainments to which admission can be had by the
public by payment, either directly or indirectly, of an admission price. (2013
Code)
3-3-2: LICENSE AND COMPLIANCE REQUIRED:
   A.   License Required: No person shall engage in the following acts in the
village without having first obtained an amusement license:
      1.   Operate a theater.
      2.   Operate a billiard center.
      3.   Operate a bowling alley.
      4.   Own, operate, maintain, sell or keep for operation a mechanical
amusement device.
      5.   Conduct or operate a public skating rink.
   B.   Compliance With Provisions: The licensee, agent or employee shall
comply with the provisions of this chapter. (2013 Code)
3-3-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; INVESTIGATION:
   A.   All applications for an amusement license shall conform to the
following requirements:
      1.   Be made in writing to the village clerk, verified by the applicant
and accompanied by the license fee required.
      2.   State the name, age and address of the applicant and, if the
applicant is a corporation, the name of its officers and directors.
      3.   State the location of the place where the amusement device or
facility is to be located and operated.
      4.   State the number of amusement devices, alleys, tables, greens,
screens, etc., as may be applicable to the particular business to be conducted.
      5.   Include a detailed scale layout of the operation, showing the
location of the greens, tables, alleys, screens, lighting, fences, buildings,
structures and other equipment.
      6.   State the name(s) of the manager(s) hired to supervise the
particular operation.
      7.   Include such other and further information as may be required by the
village clerk.
   B.   The application for a license or renewal of a license shall be made
upon forms furnished by the village clerk and shall include the date and place
of conviction of any person named therein for any crime other than minor
traffic violations committed during the period of ten (10) years prior to the
date of application, including a statement of the crime of which such person
was convicted.
   C.   The chief of police shall investigate any and all applications for a
license and shall submit a report to the village. (2013 Code)
3-3-4: LICENSE FEE:
   A.   Fee Established; Exemptions: The annual fee for an amusement license
shall be ten dollars ($10.00). The fee provided for in this section may be
waived upon application to the board of trustees in the case of limited
performances or engagements by a nonprofit organization.
   B.   Fee Not Transferable Or Prorated: The fee provided for herein is not
transferable, nor may it be prorated; except, that the fee for theaters,
billiard tables and amusement devices shall be paid for the number of screens,
tables or machines available for use, and the licenses are valid for different
tables or machines as may be replaced or changed from time to time during the
year; provided, that the license fee is paid for the maximum number of machines
or tables used on the applicant's premises at any one time. (2013 Code)
3-3-5: LIABILITY INSURANCE:
Each licensee shall keep in force liability insurance of a minimum of seven
hundred fifty thousand dollars ($750,000.00) combined single limit liability
coverage for injury to or death of any one person or persons or damages/
destruction of property in any one accident by a corporation or corporations
authorized to write insurance in the state during the license year. It shall
appear on such policy that the village shall be notified, in writing, at least
thirty (30) days prior to the cancellation of such policy of insurance. (2013
Code)
3-3-6: TERM OF LICENSE; NONTRANSFERABILITY:
Each license shall expire on December 31 next after its issuance and shall not
be transferable from one person to another. (2013 Code)
3-3-7: LICENSE AND CAPACITY TO BE POSTED:
Every entertainment license shall be conspicuously posted about the place for
which the license is issued and shall be exhibited to any person upon request.
All amusement facilities shall post the capacity limitation for their premises
in a conspicuous place. (2013 Code)
3-3-8: PERSONS ON DUTY:
There shall be on duty at all times that the operation of a billiard center,
bowling alley, mechanical or electronic amusement device, public skating rink,
theater or game room is open to the public an adult operator or manager who
understands the operation of all equipment used on the premises. It shall be
the duty of the licensee and his manager to remain on the premises at all times
and enforce the provisions of subsection 3-3-9A of this chapter. (2013 Code)
3-3-9: CONDUCT OF BUSINESS:
   A.   Code Of Conduct:
      1.   The licensee, under this chapter, shall follow and enforce the
following code of conduct for the licensed premises:
         a.   Truants from school shall not be permitted to enter or remain on
the premises.
         b.   No person violating any curfew law or ordinance shall be
permitted to enter or remain on the licensed premises.
         c.   No person soliciting to vice or any other unlawful purpose shall
be permitted to enter or remain on the licensed premises.
         d.   No person selling, transferring, giving, using or in possession
of any "controlled substance", as defined by Illinois Compiled Statutes, shall
be permitted to enter or remain on the premises or remain in the area directly
adjacent to the premises.
         e.   No person shall be permitted to harass, threaten or annoy any
persons.
         f.   No person shall loiter inside or outside a billiard center.
Persons not engaging in billiard or pool play or waiting their turn to play
shall be prohibited from the billiard center except in cases of an owner
sanctioned tournament or contest. Persons shall be prohibited from loitering on
the property outside the billiard center, including the parking lot.
      2.   The licensee under this chapter shall post in plain view a copy of
the above rules of conduct as well as a copy of the house rules and hours of
operation in a minimum of one inch (1") letters.
   B.   Maintenance Of Order: It shall be the responsibility of the licensee
under this chapter to maintain order on the licensed premises at all times.
(2013 Code)
3-3-10: PROHIBITED ACTS AND CONDITIONS:
   A.   Alcoholic Beverages On Licensed Premises: No person shall, in any
licensed premises or in any anteroom, corridor, cloakroom, hallway or dressing
room thereof or in any room connecting therewith, drink any alcoholic
beverages; nor shall any licensee hereunder suffer or permit any person to
drink any alcoholic beverages in or on any licensed premises over which such
licensee has control.
   B.   Gambling In Billiard Centers:
      1.   It shall be unlawful for the owner or operator of any licensed
billiard center to permit the same to be used for gambling or for the making of
bets or wagers.
      2.   It shall be unlawful for the licensee or the owner or operator of a
billiard center to give any money, token, merchandise or any other thing of
value or any reward or prize in lieu of free games.
      3.   No person shall keep, maintain, sell or permit to be operated in his
billiard center any billiard table, pool table or other equipment which has
been converted into an automatic payoff device which shall discharge coins,
checks or other tokens to the operator or player of such table or equipment. No
person shall convert any billiard table, pool table or other equipment into an
automatic payoff device.
      4.   Any billiard or pool table which has been utilized in violation of
this subsection may be seized and destroyed in compliance with the provisions
of the state statutes relating to gambling devices. (2013 Code)
3-3-11: REQUIREMENTS FOR SPECIFIC AMUSEMENT ESTABLISHMENTS:
   A.   Skating Rinks, Billiard Centers, Bowling Alleys And Amusement Centers:
      1.   Lighting: Every skating rink, billiard center, bowling alley and
place having mechanical amusement devices shall be illuminated while in public
use, and operation thereof while the lights are extinguished or turned so low
as to not give proper vision is hereby prohibited.
      2.   Open View: The operation of a skating rink, billiard center, bowling
alley and premises having mechanical amusement devices shall at all times be
conducted in open view of the public. Such amusements shall not be enclosed
from the public in private rooms.
      3.   Hours Of Operation For Billiard Centers; Minors:
         a.   A billiard center shall be closed by one o'clock (1:00) A.M. each
night and may not be open until nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. on weekdays and
Saturdays or until twelve o'clock (12:00) noon on Sundays.
         b.   No one under the age of sixteen (16) shall be permitted on the
premises of a billiard center after nine o'clock (9:00) P.M. except when
accompanied by a parent or legal guardian; no one under the age of eighteen
(18) shall be permitted on the premises of a billiard center after ten o'clock
(10:00) P.M. except when accompanied by a parent or legal guardian.
   B.   Theaters:
      1.   It shall be unlawful for any person to show or exhibit in a public
place or in a place to which the public is admitted any motion picture, whether
an admission is charged or not, without exhibiting a classification notice
therefor as provided in this subsection. The classification notice required in
this subsection shall designate the rating applied to the motion picture to be
exhibited. Such classification notice shall contain one of the ratings used by
the Motion Picture Association Of America, Inc.
      2.   It shall be unlawful for any person to show or exhibit or cause to
be shown or exhibited to any person under the age of seventeen (17) any picture
designated R unless accompanied by a parent or adult guardian. It shall be
unlawful for any person to show or exhibit or cause to be shown or exhibited to
any person under the age of seventeen (17) any picture designated X.
      3.   Any person who admits a person not qualified to view a motion
picture under the provisions of this subsection to a performance of a picture
designated R or X shall be presumed to have violated the provisions of this
subsection. Such prima facie case of violation may be rebutted by a showing
that the motion picture in question has been improperly classified.
      4.   The rating provided by this subsection shall be that imposed upon
such motion picture by the Motion Picture Association Of America, Inc., if the
motion picture has been classified by that organization. In the event no
classification has been imposed by such motion picture organization, the person
or organization showing or exhibiting such motion picture shall be responsible
for designating the classification in accordance with standards prescribed by
the Motion Picture Association Of America, Inc., and shall restrict admission
to persons under the age of seventeen (17) in accordance with the standards set
forth in the ratings as provided in this subsection.
      5.   The notice of classification provided for in this subsection shall
be posted at or near the entrance of the theater, hall, room or place where any
motion picture is being exhibited, at such a place and in such a position that
it may easily be read by any person entering such theater, hall, room or place,
at any time when any such motion picture is being exhibited. Film ratings shall
be included in all advertising.
      6.   When motion pictures having a different rating are being shown
together as double or triple features, they shall all be assigned the rating of
the picture carrying the most restrictive rating.
      7.   No licensee shall display on the exterior of an indoor theater or
show or exhibit at any drive-in theater in such a manner that passersby view or
are likely to view any picture, photograph, drawing or similar visual
representation or image of a person or portion of the human body which depicts
sexual conduct, sexual excitement or sadomasochistic abuse. (2013 Code)
3-3-12: ADDITIONAL REQUIREMENTS:
The village may impose other reasonable restrictions or conditions as it deems
necessary to provide for public health, safety, and welfare. (2013 Code)
3-3-13: REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION OF LICENSE:
All licenses granted hereunder shall be revocable for cause at any time. Said
licenses may be suspended for such period as the board of trustees may
prescribe or may be revoked by the board of trustees, and such revocation or
suspension shall be made on reasonable hearing prescribed by the board of
trustees. "Cause" shall include any violation of this chapter. If there shall
be two (2) convictions for violations of this chapter, whether such violations
are the same or different provisions of this chapter, the second such
conviction shall be cause for revocation of the license after hearing
prescribed by the board of trustees. No refund fee shall be paid on revocation.
(2013 Code)
ARTICLE A. VIDEO GAMING
SECTION:
3-3A-1: Regulations
3-3A-2: Applicability Of Provisions
3-3A-3: Definitions
3-3A-4: License
3-3A-5: License Application Requirements
3-3A-6: Application Filing; Renewals
3-3A-7: License Fees
3-3A-8: License Revocation Or Suspension
3-3A-9: Limitation On Number Of Video Gaming Licenses
3-3A-10: Limitation On Number Of Video Gaming Terminals On Premises
3-3A-11: Prohibition
3-3A-12: Exceptions
3-3A-13: Licensed Establishments
3-3A-14: Seizure Of Unauthorized Gambling Devices And Gambling Funds
3-3A-1: REGULATIONS:
The village hereby formally declares that there shall be no village ordinance,
policy or regulation prohibiting the implementation within the village of
licenses in compliance with the Illinois video gaming act, 230 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 40/1 et seq.; except, that such video gaming devices as may
be allowable under the Illinois video gaming act shall constitute amusement
devices with the village and are thus required to additionally be in compliance
with the licensing and regulatory provisions of such applicable village
ordinances, including, but not being limited to, the provisions therein in
reference to the number of amusement devices allowable and the license fee per
device required by such ordinances. (Ord. 2012-27, 8-8-2012)
3-3A-2: APPLICABILITY OF PROVISIONS:
The provisions of this chapter, except as otherwise provided, shall apply to
all video gaming as hereinafter defined, whether specifically licensed or
regulated under other provisions of this code or other ordinances, or not.
(Ord. 2022-04, 2-10-2022)
3-3A-3: DEFINITIONS:
BOARD:         The Illinois Gaming Board.
COMMERCIAL
MOTOR          As defined in Section 18b-101 of the Illinois Vehicle Code, 625 ILCS 5/18b-101.
VEHICLES:
               Any business licensed by the State of Illinois to have or operate a video gaming
LICENSED       device in the Village, including any licensed fraternal establishment, licensed
ESTABLISHMENT: veterans establishment, licensed truck stop establishment and licensed large
               truck stop establishment as those terms are defined in the VGA, 230 ILCS 40/5.
LICENSED       The location where a qualified fraternal organization that derives its charter
FRATERNAL      from a national fraternal organization regularly meets.
ESTABLISHMENT:
               A facility located within three road miles from a freeway interchange, as
               measured in accordance with the Department of Transportation’s rules regarding
               the criteria for the installation of business signs: (i) that is at least a
LICENSED LARGE three-acre facility with a convenience store; (ii) with separate diesel islands
TRUCK STOP     for fueling commercial motor vehicles; (iii) that sells at retail more than
ESTABLISHMENT: 50,000 gallons of diesel or biodiesel fuel per month; and (iv) with parking
               spaces for commercial motor vehicles. The requirement of item (iii) of this
               definition may be met by showing that estimated future sales or past sales
               average at least 50,000 gallons per month.
               A facility (i) that is at least a three-acre facility with a convenience store;
LICENSED TRUCK (ii) with separate diesel islands for fueling commercial motor vehicles; (iii)
STOP           that sells at retail more than 10,000 gallons of diesel or biodiesel fuel per
ESTABLISHMENT: month; and (iv) with parking spaces for commercial motor vehicles. The
               requirement of item (iii) of this paragraph may be met by showing that estimated
               future sales or past sales average at least 10,000 gallons per month.
LICENSED       The location where a qualified veterans organization that derives its charter
VETERANS       from a national veterans organization regularly meets.
ESTABLISHMENT:
               Any electronic video game machine that, upon insertion of cash, is available to
               play or simulate the play of a video game, including but not limited to, video
VIDEO GAMING   poker, line up and blackjack, as authorized by the Board utilizing a video
TERMINAL:      display and microprocessors in which the player may receive free games or
               credits that can be redeemed for cash. The term does not include a machine that
               directly dispenses coins, cash or tokens or is for amusement purposes only.
               (Ord. 2022-04, 2-10-2022)
 
3-3A-4: LICENSE:
   A.   No person, either as owner, lessee, manager, officer or agent, or in
any other capacity, shall operate or permit to be operated any video gaming
terminal, as defined herein, at any premises within the Village without first
having obtained a video gaming license from the Village. The license provided
for in this Article shall permit a licensee to operate video gaming terminals
at the specified establishment.
   B.   No applicant, including any person, either as owner, lessee, manager,
officer or agent, shall be eligible for a video gaming license from the
Village, nor shall an existing license holder be entitled to maintain a video
gaming license, unless each of the following requirements are met and continue
to be met:
      1.   The applicant holds the appropriate certificate or license from the
State of Illinois permitting video gaming and is in good standing with same;
      2.   The establishment must maintain customer seating outside of the
gaming area but within the premises at a ratio of at least five seats for each
permitted video gaming terminal;
      3.   The applicant is not in arrears in any tax, fee or bill due to the
Village or State of Illinois;
      4.   The applicant has completed and complies with all the application
requirements set forth in Section 4 of this Article and is not disqualified due
to a felony, gambling offense, or crime of moral turpitude; and
      5.   The establishment is located outside of a residential zoning
district.
   C.   The Village President shall be the approving authority for all
licenses. In the event a licensee or prospective licensee disagrees with any
action taken by the Village President, an appeal may be made directly to the
President and Board of Trustees of the Village at its next regularly scheduled
meeting after written notice of the action from which an appeal is made. (Ord.
2022-04, 2-10-2022)
3-3A-5: LICENSE APPLICATION REQUIREMENTS:
The license applicant shall provide the following information to the Village on
a form provided by the Village:
   A.   The legal name of the establishment;
   B.   The business name of the establishment;
   C.   The address of the establishment where the video gaming terminals are
to be located;
   D.   The type of establishment, including whether it is classified as a
veteran, fraternal, regular truck stop, large truck stop or liquor
establishment and supporting documentation demonstrating the classification;
   E.   A floor plan, drawn to scale using a computer, detailing the overall
layout of the establishment, including the location and count of dining
seating, the location and count of video gaming terminals and seating for said
terminals, and other significant features of the establishment, including exit
locations, restrooms and other equipment. A high-resolution electronic copy of
the floor plan as well as a paper printed copy (no smaller than 11 inches by 17
inches) shall be submitted at the time of application; hand-drawn floor plans
and floor plans not including a scale will not be accepted;
   F.   The amount of time the establishment has been in business under the
ownership of the applicant at the location where video gaming is proposed to
take place;
   G.   The business office address of the establishment if different from the
address of the establishment;
   H.   In the case of a corporation, limited liability company or trust, the
name and address of an agent authorized and designated to accept service on
behalf of the licensee;
   I.   A phone number for the establishment;
   J.   An e-mail address for the establishment;
   K.   The name and address of every person owning more than a 5% share of the
establishment;
   L.   The name, address, phone number and e-mail address of any terminal
operator or distributor proposed to own, service or maintain video gaming
terminals at the establishment;
   M.   A copy of the establishment’s State of Illinois video gaming license;
   N.   In the case of a corporation, limited liability company or partnership,
a copy of the establishment’s state certificate of good standing;
   O.   A statement as to the number of video gaming terminals which the
establishment proposes to have on its premises (not to exceed five for all
establishments);
   P.   A statement that the establishment is not in arrears in any tax, fee or
bill due to the Village or State of Illinois;
   Q.   A statement that the establishment agrees to abide by all state and
federal laws and any local ordinance;
   R.   A statement that no manager or owner with more than 5% interest in the
establishment has ever been convicted of a felony, a gambling offense or a
crime of moral turpitude. In the event that an establishment cannot provide
such statement, the establishment may apply for a certificate of rehabilitation
from the Village President indicating that the individual who would disqualify
the establishment from obtaining the video gaming license has been
rehabilitated and is no longer a threat to violate the law. The Village
President may consider the nature of the offense, the length of time since the
offense, the length of time since release from custody and other factors to
determine if the individual has been rehabilitated such that he or she is no
longer likely to commit another offense;
   S.   If the application is for a new establishment based on the business
model of another existing location, information regarding the existing business
location must be provided, including the type of business, the gross receipts
as compared to any video gaming revenue for the prior 12-month period, proof of
the length of time the existing business has been operational and proof of
ownership verifying the applicant’s ownership rights. (Ord. 2022-04, 2-10-2022)
3-3A-6: APPLICATION FILING; RENEWALS:
   A.   Applications shall be processed by the Village Clerk on a first come,
first served basis. Every application shall be date and time stamped upon
filing. An application received in the mail shall be considered filed on the
date and time it is opened by the Village Clerk’s department.
   B.   Every video gaming license holder shall be required to file a renewal
application, which may contain the same or similar information as set forth in
Section 4. Renewal applications shall be due on or before July 1st unless that
day falls on a holiday, in which case the application may be received by the
Clerk on the following business day. (Ord. 2022-04, 2-10-2022)
3-3A-7: LICENSE FEES:
The license for a video gaming terminal operator’s license or a video gaming
terminal establishment license shall be $-0- annually.
The video gaming terminal registration fee shall be $250.00 per terminal
annually (August 1st through June 30th). The cost of these fees shall be shared
equally between the terminal operator and the applicable licensed
establishment, per Illinois law. However, the licensed establishment is
obligated to pay the Village in full by the due date.
The application fee is not subject to reimbursement or refund upon denial of a
license.
Said fees are not subject to proration or refund and are due prior to issuance
of the license.
All licenses required by this division shall be prominently displayed next to
the video gaming terminal. (Ord. 2022-04, 2-10-2022; amd. Ord. 2022-27, 8-11-
2022)
3-3A-8: LICENSE REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION:
The Village President, at any time, may notify any licensee under this division
within five (5) business days of any charge of a violation of any of the
provisions of this Article in connection with the operation of any video gaming
terminal. After a hearing presided over by the Village President, the Village
President may order the revocation of the license upon a finding that the
violation has occurred, and the license shall thereupon be terminated. The
licensee may appeal the revocation as prescribed in Section
3-3A-4(F).
In the event of the revocation or denial of any license or registration under
this Section, such person shall not be issued any license provided for in this
Article for one calendar year following the revocation or any appeal thereof.
(Ord. 2022-04, 2-10-2022)
3-3A-9: LIMITATION ON NUMBER OF VIDEO GAMING LICENSES:
There shall be no more than eleven (11) establishments licensed to operate
video gaming terminals in the Village at any given time, and no more than
seventy (70) total gaming terminals in the Village at any given time. (Ord.
2022-04, 2-10-2022; amd. Ord. 2022-27, 8-11-2022; Ord. 2022-32, 9-8-2022)
3-3A-10: LIMITATION ON NUMBER OF VIDEO GAMING TERMINALS ON PREMISES:
There shall be no more than six (6) video gaming terminals allowed and permits
issued therefore under this Article for each licensee at any one location,
other than a licensed large truck stop establishment.
There shall be no more than ten (10) video gaming terminals allowed and permits
issued therefore under this Article for each licensee at any licensed large
truck stop establishment. (Ord. 2022-04, 2-10-2022)
3-3A-11: PROHIBITION:
Except as otherwise excepted in this Article, it shall be unlawful for any
person to gamble within the corporate limits of the Village, or for any person
or entity which owns, occupies or controls an establishment within the Village
to knowingly permit others to gamble on the premises. (Ord. 2022-04, 2-10-2022)
3-3A-12: EXCEPTIONS:
Nothing in this Article shall be deemed to prohibit or make unlawful the
following activities or forms of gambling: the keeping, possession, ownership,
use or playing of a video gaming terminal in a licensed establishment, licensed
truck stop establishment, licensed fraternal establishment or licensed veterans
establishment, which is licensed by the Board to conduct or allow such specific
activities under the VGA, 230 ILCS 40/1, et seq. (Ord. 2022-04, 2-10-2022)
3-3A-13: LICENSED ESTABLISHMENTS:
Any business, liquor or food licensee within the corporate limits of the
Village that allows gambling to occur on premises in violation of this Section
shall be subject to having his/her/its license immediately revoked for a period
of sixty (60) days. Any business, liquor or food licensee within the corporate
limits of the Village that allows gambling to occur on premises in violation of
this Article a second time shall have his/her/its license permanently revoked
and, thereafter, barred from obtaining any business, liquor or food license
within the Village. (Ord. 2022-04, 2-10-2022)
3-3A-14: SEIZURE OF UNAUTHORIZED GAMBLING DEVICES AND GAMBLING FUNDS:
Any gambling device which is not authorized by this Article shall be subject to
immediate seizure and confiscation by the Village. Any money or other thing of
value intrinsically related to acts of gambling not authorized by this Article
shall be seized and forfeited as contraband. Disposition of such gambling
devices and funds seized or confiscated shall be made in accordance with the
law. (Ord. 2022-04, 2-10-2022)
CHAPTER 4
PEDDLERS, SOLICITORS AND TRANSIENT MERCHANTS
SECTION:
3-4-1: Peddlers And Transient Merchants
3-4-1-1: Definitions
3-4-1-2: License Required
3-4-1-3: Applications For Licenses; Fees
3-4-1-4: Conditions Of Licenses
3-4-1-5: Exemptions From Provisions
3-4-1-6: Revocation Of License
3-4-1-7: Penalty
3-4-2: Tag Day Provisions
3-4-3: Invitation And/Or Consent For Soliciting Or Peddling
3-4-1: PEDDLERS AND TRANSIENT MERCHANTS:
3-4-1-1: DEFINITIONS:
FARMER'S MARKET: Any person selling farm or homegrown produce temporarily in
any place in the Village, and who, for the purpose of conducting such business,
occupies any lot, building, room, vehicle, or structure of any kind.
PEDDLER: Any person who goes from house to house, from place to place or from
street to street conveying or transporting for sale goods, wares or
merchandise, offering or exposing the goods, wares or merchandise for sale, or
making sales and delivering articles to purchasers; or any person who, for
himself or another, hires, leases, uses or occupies any vehicle or other place
or facility within the Village for the purpose of selling or offering for sale
any goods, wares or merchandise.
TRANSIENT MERCHANT: Any person engaging temporarily in retail or wholesale sale
of goods, wares or merchandise in any place in the Village, and who, for the
purpose of conducting such business, occupies any lot, building, room, vehicle
or structure of any kind. (Ord. 2017-15, 6-14-2017)
3-4-1-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of hawker,
peddler or transient merchant of any merchandise, article or thing without
having first secured a license therefor from the Village Clerk. (Ord. 2017-15,
6-14-2017)
3-4-1-3: APPLICATIONS FOR LICENSES; FEES:
   A.   Peddlers:
      1.   Application For License: Application for a peddler's license shall
be made to the Village Clerk and shall set forth:
         a.   The names and addresses of all persons who will engage in
peddling pursuant to the license to be granted;
         b.   A description of the goods, merchandise or services to be
peddled;
         c.   The dates and times during which such peddling will occur
pursuant to the license applied for; and
         d.   The applicant's certificate of registration number issued by the
State Department of Revenue, and other satisfactory evidence approved by
Village that sales made within the Village will be reported as taxable sales
within the Village by the applicant.
      2.   License Fees: The fee for a peddler's license shall be:
         a.   Daily License: Twenty five dollars ($25.00) per person peddling
for a one day license. The total number to be annually issued for a one day
license shall not exceed three (3).
         b.   Summer License: Five hundred dollars ($500.00) for a "summer
license fee" which is defined as from nine o'clock (9:00) A.M., May 1 until
twelve o'clock (12:00) noon, September 30. The total number to be annually
issued for a summer license shall not exceed three (3).
         c.   Thirty Day License: One hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) for a
thirty (30) day license, expiring at one minute after twelve o'clock (12:01)
A.M. on the thirtieth (30th) day from the issuance date, with the issuance date
being day one of the license period. The total number to be annually issued for
a thirty (30) day license shall not exceed three (3).
   B.   Transient Merchants:
      1.   Application For License: Application for a transient merchant's
license shall be made to the Village Clerk and shall set forth:
         a.   The name and address of the applicant and all persons who will be
employed by the applicant or the applicant's business during the period of the
license applied for;
         b.   A specific description of the goods, merchandise or services to
be offered for sale;
         c.   The exact location in the Village from which the business will be
conducted during the license period;
         d.   The applicant's State certificate of registration number issued
by the State Department of Revenue, and such other satisfactory evidence
approved by Village that sales made within the Village will be reported as
taxable sales within the Village by the applicant; and
         e.   The identity of the owner of the location from which the
transient merchant business will be conducted, and the application shall be
executed by the owner of the location as evidence of the applicant's
authorization to utilize the property, or in lieu thereof, the applicant may
submit a written lease or other written evidence approved by Village of the
applicant's authorization to conduct business upon the property. An owner of
property allowing a transient merchant or flea market to operate thereon is
responsible for the acts of those selling or soliciting on his/her property and
is punishable in the same manner as the license holder.
      2.   License Fees: The fees for transient merchant licenses shall be:
         a.   Daily License: Twenty five dollars ($25.00) for a one day
license. The total number to be annually issued for a one-day license shall not
exceed three (3).
         b.   Summer License: Five hundred dollars ($500.00) for a "summer
license fee" which is defined as from eight o'clock (8:00) A.M., May 1 until
twelve o'clock (12:00) noon, September 30. The total number to be annually
issued for a summer license shall not exceed three (3).
         c.   Thirty Day License: One hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) for a
thirty (30) day license, expiring at one minute after twelve o'clock (12:01)
A.M. on the thirtieth (30th) day from the issuance date, with the issuance date
being day one of the license period. The total number to be annually issued for
a thirty (30) day license shall not exceed three (3).
   C.   Flea Markets:
      1.   Application For License: A property owner or landlord who is
providing sales space to ten (10) or more transient merchants shall submit a
flea market application to the Village Clerk setting forth:
         a.   The applicant's name and address;
         b.   The address of the flea market location, such location to be
approved by the Village;
         c.   The dates and times during which the flea market will be
operating; and
         d.   The applicant's State certificate of registration number issued
by the State Department of Revenue, and other satisfactory evidence that sales
made within the Village will be reported as taxable sales within the Village by
the applicant.
      2.   License Fees: The fees for flea market licenses shall be:
 
Number Of Participating Merchants Fee Per Weekend
   10 to 20                    $40.00
   21 to 40                    50.00
   More than 40                60.00
 
   D.   Cash Deposit/Bonds Prerequisite To Issuance: Before any license shall
be issued in the Village under this section, the applicant shall file with the
Village Clerk a bond with guarantees running to the Village in the sum of five
hundred dollars ($500.00) executed by the applicant, as principal, with good
and sufficient sureties upon which service of process may be made in the State.
Such bond shall be secured by a cash deposit or a surety bond of five hundred
dollars ($500.00) with the Village Clerk's Office. Such bond shall be
conditioned upon the undertaking that the applicant shall comply fully with all
of the sections of this Code and the provisions of the ordinances of the
Village and the statutes of the State regulating and concerning the sale of
goods, wares and merchandise, or laws requiring the payment of sales taxes or
other fees imposed by law, and payment of all fees or taxes owed by the
applicant and judgments rendered against the applicant for any violation of
this Code, the ordinances or statutes, or any of them, together with all
judgments and costs that may be recovered against him by any person for damage
growing out of any misrepresentation or deception practiced on any person
transacting such business with such applicant, whether such misrepresentations
or deceptions were made or practiced by the owners or by their servants, agents
or employees, either at the time of making the sale or through any
advertisement of any character whatsoever, printed or circulated with reference
to the goods, wares and merchandise sold or any part thereof. Action on the
bond may be brought in the name of the Village to the use of the aggrieved
person or by the Village if for the collection of taxes or fees. Such bond must
be approved by the Village Attorney, both as to form and as to the
responsibility of the sureties thereon. The bond shall be in force and effect
for a two-year period after application. The Village Clerk shall retain such
deposit or bond for up to two (2) years for the benefit of any person who
suffers loss or damage as a result of the purchase of merchandise from such
person licensed under this section or as a result of the negligent or
intentionally tortuous act of the person licensed under this section. The
Village shall pay any portion of the bond or deposit to any person in
accordance with the order of a court without making an independent finding as
to the amount of the bond or deposit that is payable to that person. Any
balance of such deposit held by the Village after the expiration of a license
held by a person shall be refunded to the licensee, within two (2) years of
license expiration.
   E.   Waiver: The requirement of a license fee, cash deposit, and/or posting
of a bond may be waived by the Village if applicant is an accredited public
and/or private school district, or a registered youth organization or
charitable organization. (Ord. 2017-15, 6-14-2017)
3-4-1-4: CONDITIONS OF LICENSES:
   A.   Days And Hours Peddling Prohibited: No peddler shall operate under the
registration or license issued under this section
3-4-1 on Sundays or holidays. No peddler shall call at residences before nine
o'clock (9:00) A.M. or after five o'clock (5:00) P.M., except at the prior
invitation or request of the occupant of the residence.
   B.   Sales Location Of Transient Merchants: Transient merchants shall submit
an IDOR St-2 (multiple site form) indicating the appropriate location code for
sales.
   C.   Signs, Debris And Hours: All peddlers, transient merchants, and those
participating in a farmers' market shall observe the following conditions of
their license:
      1.   All signage shall be approved by the Zoning Enforcement Officer and
in compliance with the Village sign ordinance, section
10-15-1 et seq., of this Code.
      2.   Unless otherwise specifically provided in the license, at the close
of the licensed business day, the area of sale should be free of debris and all
of the seller items, including but not limited to vehicles and trailers,
removed from the premises.
      3.   Unless otherwise specifically provided in such license operating
hours are eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. until seven o'clock (7:00) P.M., daily for
transient merchant license holders.
   D.   No Alcohol: No license granted under this section shall permit a
license holder to offer, sell, or provide any alcoholic beverages.
   E.   Food/Health: Any license holder under this section must comply with all
County and State Health Code and food preparation/sale requirements,
regulations, and laws.
   F.   Records Of Sales; Collection Of Taxes: Each license holder not exempt
from remitting taxes on sales shall, if requested by the Village Clerk, certify
under oath to the Village Clerk the total amount of sales in the Village and
send a copy of the merchant's report of sales to the State under the Retailers
Occupation Tax Act, 35 Illinois Compiled Statutes 120/1 et seq. Such
information shall be delivered to the Village Clerk within fifteen (15) days
after any request. The Village Clerk shall be entitled to examine the records
of such merchant in order to verify the proper collection of such taxes.
   G.   Parking/Access: All transient merchant and flea market locations must
have adequate access points for entry/exit and parking for customers as
determined by the Chief of Police or his designee. Failure to provide such
shall be cause for denial of license or immediate revocation of such if already
issued.
   H.   Zoning: No transient merchant nor flea market licenses will be issued
for locations located in areas zoned residential under the Village zoning
ordinance.
   I.   Selling From Vehicles On Streets: No person shall allow a vehicle or
any form of conveyance to remain standing at one located on a street or other
public property for the purpose of the display for sale or for selling any
goods or services for longer than five (5) minutes at a time.
   J.   License Restriction In Congested Areas: The Village Board hereby
determines that, on certain dates, congestion in the Village or a part of the
Village will be too great to permit transient merchants or a particular type of
transient merchant to conduct sales within that area. The Chief of Police or
his designee may limit the number and type of transient merchant licenses in a
particular area based on projected traffic and pedestrian safety. In such
cases, the Village President may determine that all transient merchants or a
class thereof shall only sell goods in a particular area. The Chief of Police
or his designee may limit the number and type of licenses available for use in
the congested area. The Chief of Police or his designee may require sales to be
made by peddlers only from stationary locations on designated portions of the
Village's right-of-way or other conditions that serve to enhance public safety
in congested areas. The Chief of Police or his designee shall provide notice to
persons who apply for or who have transient merchant licenses that such license
is invalid for the times and places stated in the Chief of Police or his
designee's determination. Such notice shall inform such persons of the
conditions, if any, and procedure for requesting permission to sell in the
congested area. If more than the number of licenses determined by the Chief of
Police or his designee to be available for sales in a congested area are
requested, the Clerk shall conduct a lottery for the license use on that date
and times. No person shall engage in the business of transient merchant at a
time or location for which the Chief of Police or his designee has determined
that permits are limited or in violation of the terms of the congested area
conditions, unless such person's license has been validated for sales in a
congested area.
   K.   Display Of Certificate Or License: Each transient merchant or
charitable solicitor or his agents and employees shall at all times while
soliciting or canvassing within the Village carry upon his person the
registration certificate identification or license required by this chapter and
shall exhibit the certificate or license upon request to any law enforcement
officer or Village official. (Ord. 2017-15, 6-14-2017)
3-4-1-5: EXEMPTIONS FROM PROVISIONS:
   A.   Peddlers: The provisions of this section
3-4-1 shall not apply to officers or employees of the Village, County, State
and Federal governments or subdivisions thereof, when on official business. No
peddler's license pursuant to this section
3-4-1 shall be required for any peddler who solicits only at businesses within
the Village, who solicits at residences within the Village only upon the
express invitation of the occupant thereof or who is engaged in peddling for
the purpose of fundraising for a governmental entity or for a church,
charitable institution or other not-for-profit organization; provided, that any
such entity or organization relying upon this exemption shall notify the Chief
of Police at least one week prior to any scheduled peddling activities of its
reliance upon this exception and shall provide such information and
substantiation thereof as requested by the Chief of Police.
   B.   Transient Merchants: The provisions of this section
3-4-1 shall not apply to:
      1.   Transient merchants participating in the LaSalle County Historical
Society Burgoo Festival and located within the festival area as designated by
the Village during the entire weekend of Burgoo Festival.
      2.   Persons who are engaged in selling farm, garden or similar produce
in the Village; provided, that the person is participating in a farmers'
market.
      3.   Temporary events sponsored or approved in advance by the Village
Board. (Ord. 2017-15, 6-14-2017)
3-4-1-6: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
Any licensed peddler, hawker or transient merchant who shall be guilty of any
fraud, cheating or misrepresentation, whether individually or through an
employee, while acting as a peddler, hawker or transient merchant in the
Village, or who shall barter, sell or peddle any goods or merchandise or wares,
other than those specified in the individual's application for a license, shall
be fined as provided in section
3-4-1-7 of this chapter, may have his license revoked by the Village President
for such offense, and is subject to forfeiture of the cash deposit and/or bond
provided for herein. (Ord. 2017-15, 6-14-2017)
3-4-1-7: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this section
3-4-1 shall be fined not less than seventy five dollars ($75.00) nor more than
seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense, and a separate offense
shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or
continues. In addition, the Village may retain any cash deposit or recover on
any bond, and suspend and/or revoke a license of anyone who violates any
provision of this section for up to one year for a first offense and
permanently for a repeat offender. (Ord. 2017-15, 6-14-2017)
3-4-2: TAG DAY PROVISIONS:
   A.   Permit Required: It shall be unlawful for any person to go from house
to house soliciting funds or subscriptions or to publicly solicit, either in
person or by agent, upon the public street, sidewalks or any other public place
in the Village, subscriptions for charitable or religious or educational or
other organizations or purposes, whether presents or gifts of money or promises
are sought, without having first secured a permit therefor.
   B.   Applications For Permit: Applications for such permits shall be made to
the Clerk and shall be referred to the President and Board of Trustees, and no
such permit shall be issued except upon the order of the President and Board of
Trustees.
   C.   Penalty: Any person violating any provisions of this section shall be
fined as provided in section
1-4-1 of this Code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed
committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. (Ord.
2017-15, 6-14-2017)
3-4-3: INVITATION AND/OR CONSENT FOR SOLICITING OR PEDDLING:
   A.   Soliciting Or Peddling: It shall be unlawful for any person to go upon
the premises of another for the purposes of soliciting orders, selling or
peddling without the consent or invitation of the owner or occupant.
   B.   Penalty: Any person violating any provision of this section shall be
fined as provided in section
1-4-1 of this Code for each violation. (Ord. 2017-15, 6-14-2017)
CHAPTER 5
JUNK DEALERS
SECTION:
3-5-1: License Required
3-5-2: Application For License; Fee
3-5-3: Lost Or Stolen Goods
3-5-4: Vehicle Requirements
3-5-5: Penalty
3-5-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to operate or carry on the business of junk dealer or to
keep any junk shop, store or place for the purchase or sale of junk, rags, old
rope, paper or bagging, old iron, brass, copper or empty bottles without having
first secured a license therefor. (1966 Code § 245)
3-5-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE; FEE:
Applications for licenses shall be made in conformance with the provisions of
the ordinances relating to licenses. The fee to be paid for such license shall
be twenty five dollars ($25.00) per year. (1966 Code §§ 246, 247; amd. 2013
Code)
3-5-3: LOST OR STOLEN GOODS:
Every keeper of a junk shop who shall receive or be in possession of any goods,
articles or things of value which may have been lost or stolen shall, upon
demand, produce such article or thing to any member of the police department
for examination. (1966 Code § 249)
3-5-4: VEHICLE REQUIREMENTS:
Every vehicle used by a junk dealer in the conduct of his business shall bear
thereon, in legible characters, the name and address of the owner and
proprietor thereof. (1966 Code § 250)
3-5-5: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be fined as provided
in section
1-4-1 of this code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed
committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. (1966
Code § 251; amd. 2013 Code)
CHAPTER 6
SCAVENGERS
SECTION:
3-6-1: Permit Required
3-6-2: Application For Permit; Issuance
3-6-3: Permit Fee
3-6-4: Vehicle Requirements And Use Restrictions
3-6-5: Disposal Of Refuse
3-6-6: Penalty
3-6-1: PERMIT REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of scavenger or
the collection or disposal of animal, human or vegetable refuse or offal
without having first secured a permit therefor. (1966 Code § 274)
3-6-2: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT; ISSUANCE:
Applications for such permits shall be made to the village clerk, and shall be
referred by him to the president and board of trustees. No such permit shall be
issued except on order of the president and board of trustees. (1966 Code §
275)
3-6-3: PERMIT FEE:
The annual fee for such permit shall be twenty five dollars ($25.00). (1966
Code § 274)
3-6-4: VEHICLE REQUIREMENTS AND USE RESTRICTIONS:
Any vehicle used by such scavenger in his business shall be watertight and
equipped with airtight covers for such portions as are used for the
transportation of refuse. It shall be unlawful for any such vehicle to be
driven over or through any street in the village during or on a Sunday. (1966
Code § 276)
3-6-5: DISPOSAL OF REFUSE:
It shall be unlawful for any scavenger to dispose of or to store any refuse in
any place within the village limits, except with the permission of the
president and board of trustees. (1966 Code § 277; amd. 2013 Code)
3-6-6: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be fined as provided
in section
1-4-1 of this code for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed
committed on each and every day during or on which a violation occurs or is
permitted to continue. (Ord. 95-18, 9-6-1995; amd. 2013 Code)
CHAPTER 7
HOTELS AND MOTELS
SECTION:
3-7-1: Definitions
3-7-2: License Required
3-7-3: Application Fee/License Fee

3-7-5: Building And Premises Requirements
3-7-6: Guests

3-7-1: DEFINITIONS:
 
       A building in which lodging or board and lodging are provided and offered to the
       public for compensation and in which access to and from all rooms is made through
HOTEL: an inside lobby or office supervised by a person in charge at all hours. As such,
       it is open to the public in contrast to an “apartment”, which is separately
       defined in this section.
       A.   An inn or group of cabins or rooms designed for occupancy by paying guests.
MOTEL: B.   A building or group of buildings in which lodging is provided to transient
       guests, offered to the public for compensation, and in which access to and from
       each room or unit is through an exterior door. (Ord. 2022-38, 12-15-2022)
 
3-7-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall conduct or operate a hotel, motel or building or part thereof
used or held out to the public as a place where sleeping accommodations are
furnished for a period of one day or more without having first secured a
license therefor. (Ord. 95-16, 9-6-1995; amd. Ord. 2022-38, 12-15-2022)
3-7-3: APPLICATION FEE/LICENSE FEE:
   A.   An application for a license under this chapter shall be made in
conformity with the general requirements of this code relating to applications
for licenses 1 .
   B.   The applicant for a license under this chapter, at the time of
presenting plans and specifications to the clerk, shall deposit with the clerk
the amount of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). Said fee shall represent the
initial application fee and shall be non-refundable, even if the license is not
issued. An annual fee for a license issued pursuant to this section shall be
four hundred dollars ($400.00) and is valid for the calendar year of issuance.
The annual fee is not pro-rated. (Ord. 95-16, 9-6-1995; amd. Ord. 2020-02, 3-
12-2020; Ord. 2022-38, 12-15-2022)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/11-30-5; 740 ILCS 90/0.01 et seq.
3-7-4: LICENSE AND LAWS POSTED:
   A.   License: The license required by this chapter shall be conspicuously
displayed in the office of the hotel or motel manager.
   B.   Laws: There shall be posted in each room of every hotel and motel, a
printed copy of the act of the general assembly relating to such buildings, to
be furnished by the state board of health. (Ord. 95-16, 9-6-1995; amd. 2013
Code; Ord. 2022-38, 12-15-2022)
3-7-5: BUILDING AND PREMISES REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Sanitary Conditions; Lighting: All premises used for hotel or motel
purposes shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition, and all portions of
such premises that are open for use by guests or by the public shall be kept
lighted at all times they are so open to use.
   B.   Heat Requirements: All such premises shall be kept heated between
October 1 and May 1 to a temperature of not less than sixty eight degrees
Fahrenheit (68°F) between the hours of seven o’clock (7:00) A.M. and ten
o’clock (10:00) P.M., and to a temperature of not less than fifty five degrees
Fahrenheit (55°F) at all other hours.
   C.   Bathrooms: Water closets and lavatories shall be available to all
guests using any hotel or motel. There shall be at least one bathroom equipped
with water closet, shower or tub and lavatory facilities for each unit on the
premises.
   D.   Exits And Fire Escapes:
      1.   No building shall be used for a hotel or motel unless it is
furnished with the number of exits and fire escapes required by the building
ordinances of the village for the construction of a new hotel or motel.
      2.   No person shall block or permit the blocking of any exit from any
premises used as a hotel or motel.
   E.   Insurance Required: Prior to obtaining a license, the owner shall
provide the village clerk with proof that liability insurance coverage in the
amount of not less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per occurrence
exists with respect to such establishment. (Ord. 95-16, 9-6-1995; amd. Ord.
2022-38, 12-15-2022)
3-7-6: GUESTS:
   A.   Registry Required: Each hotel or motel proprietor shall keep or cause
to be kept a register of guests as required by state law. Such registration or
list shall be made available for inspection by any member of the police
department at any time.
   B.   Fugitives Prohibited: No person shall knowingly permit any fugitive
from justice to stay in any hotel or motel. (Ord. 95-16, 9-6-1995; amd. Ord.
2022-38, 12-15-2022)
3-7-7: HOTEL AND MOTEL USE TAX:
   A.   Definition: A “hotel”, for purposes of the use tax set out in this
section, means any unit, building or buildings in which the public may, for a
consideration, obtain living quarters, sleeping or housekeeping accommodations.
The term includes inns, hotels, motels, tourist homes or courts, lodging
houses, rooming houses, and apartment houses, resorts, villas, hostels,
boarding houses, condominiums, and timeshare rentals.
   B.   Tax Imposed; Rate: A use tax is imposed upon all persons engaged in the
village in the business of renting, leasing or letting rooms in a “hotel” (as
defined in subsection A of this section) at a rate of five percent (5%) of the
gross rental receipts from such renting, leasing or letting, excluding,
however, from gross rental receipts, the proceeds of such renting, leasing or
letting to permanent residents of that hotel. A resident shall be deemed to be
a permanent resident of a hotel for purposes of this section if the person has
a written contract for occupancy of a room for a period of time of not less
than thirty (30) days. The rate of the tax may be increased upon approval of
the Village Board of Trustees.
   C.   Payment And Collection Of Tax; Failure To Pay: For purposes of the
administration, enforcement and collection of the tax herein provided, the
following provisions shall govern:
      1.   The tax imposed by this section is imposed pursuant to the home rule
authority of the village. This tax is not imposed pursuant to 65 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/8-3-14, entitled “hotel rooms; tax on gross rental
receipts”.
      2.   Persons subject to the tax imposed by this section may reimburse
themselves for the tax liability for such tax by separately stating such tax as
an additional charge to such other charges as imposed upon the guests or
occupants of the rooms.
      3.   Persons subject to the tax herein provided shall submit to the
office of the village clerk information on forms provided relative to the gross
rental receipts during the preceding calendar month. The forms shall be filed
with the village clerk on or before the thirtieth day of the month following
the month for which the information is provided. A payment of five percent (5%)
of the amount indicated as gross rental receipts shall be paid to the village
at the time of filing the required form. The village clerk is authorized to
enlist the services of existing village employees for purposes of
administrating and enforcing the collection of the tax herein imposed.
      4.   If for any reason any tax is not paid when due, a penalty at the
rate of one and one-half percent (11/2%) per thirty (30) day period, or portion
thereof, from the day of delinquency shall be added and collected.
      5.   a.   If the tax due is not paid within thirty (30) days after the
date it becomes due, or after a final determination is made by the village
board for a disputed amount, such charges shall constitute a lien on the real
estate for which service is applied. Such lien may be perfected and enforced
against such owner, occupant, and/or any subsequent purchases, lienholders,
mortgages, and other transferees of such property.
         b.   The village clerk is hereby authorized to file a sworn statement
showing any such delinquency in the office of the county recorder of deeds, and
the filing of such statement shall be deemed notice of lien. The statement
shall contain the following:
            (1)   A description thereof;
            (2)   The amount of money due; and
            (3)   The date when such amount became delinquent.
         c.   Any such lien may be foreclosed as any other statutory lien, and
the court costs and related legal expenses for such proceedings shall be part
of the lien and paid by the owner, occupant, and any other person interested in
the property. The exercise of any remedy by enforcement for lien claims shall
not be exclusive of any other legal remedy to collect any amounts delinquent.
         d.   The village attorney is hereby authorized to institute such
foreclosure proceedings in the name of the village and any court having
jurisdiction over such matters against any property for which a bill has
remained unpaid for sixty (60) days after the due date.
      6.   Whenever any person shall fail to pay any tax as herein provided,
the Village Attorney shall, upon the request of the village clerk, bring or
cause to be brought any action to enforce the payment of said tax on behalf of
the village in any court of competent jurisdiction.
   D.   Disposition Of Revenues: All proceeds resulting from the imposition of
the tax under this section, including penalties, shall be paid into the village
treasury and shall be credited to and deposited in the corporate general fund
of the village. (Ord. 95-16, 9-6-1995; amd. Ord. 2006-26, 6-14-2006; Ord. 2008-
27, 8-13-2008; Ord. 2009-32, 10-14-2009; Ord. 2020-02, 3-12-2020; Ord. 2022-38,
12-15-2022)
3-7-8: BOOKS AND RECORDS:
   A.   Required: It shall be the duty of every person to keep accurate and
complete books and records to which the village clerk or her deputy or
authorized representative shall at all times have access, which records shall
include a daily sheet showing:
      1.   The number of hotel or motel rooms rented during the twenty four
(24) hour period, including multiple rentals of the same hotel rooms where such
shall occur; and
      2.   The actual hotel or motel tax receipts collected for the date in
question.
   B.   Inspections: The village clerk or any person certified as her deputy or
representative may enter the premises of any hotel or motel for inspection and
examination of books and records in order to effectuate the proper
administration of this chapter and to assure the enforcement of the collection
of the tax imposed. It shall be unlawful for any person to prevent, hinder, or
interfere with the village clerk or her duly authorized deputy or
representative in the discharge of her duties. (Ord. 95-16, 9-6-1995; amd. Ord.
2022-38, 12-15-2022)
3-7-9: INSPECTIONS:
   A.   Requirements: Every hotel or motel operated or maintained in the
village shall be inspected under and by authority of the chief of police or
his/her designee as frequently as may be necessary to ensure compliance with
the provisions of this chapter. Such inspection shall cover all matters
pertaining to the sanitary conditions of the rooms, beds and bedding, including
the ventilation of all rooms or occupied space, and also all rooms occupied by
the servants or other employees, to ascertain the condition of such rooms with
respect to light, heat, ventilation and general sanitation. Such investigation
is to be sufficiently accurate and complete as to convince the chief of police
or his/her designee whether the building and premises and parts thereof comply
