      2.    The Village shall notify a residential user of the necessity to
schedule an appointment to have a new meter installed. Failure by user to
schedule and maintain a scheduled appointment within 30 days of the initial
contact by the Village shall cause the Village to issue a 10-Day Notice of
Installation Violation. Such notice shall be provided to the user by certified
mail at the address of the premises or by personal service. If the notice of
installation violation is not remedied within 10 days of delivery of the
notice, then the non-metered rate shall increase from the base rate of $10.25
per month to $60.00 per month (the "violation" rate) commencing with the next
billing period. A notice sent by certified mail and not accepted or signed for,
shall be subject to the increased $60.00 per month fee if not remedied within
15 days of the date of mailing by the Village. Once the violation is remedied,
the non-metered rate shall revert from the violation rate to the base rate
commencing with the next billing cycle until the Village commences Villagewide
use of the metered rate.
      2.   Upon installation of a meter and an initial reading of the meter by
the Village, the user shall begin payment according to the applicable meter
rate set forth in this section. (Ord. 2019-15, 5-9-2019)
   C.   Water Service Maintenance Fee: The water service maintenance fee for
all users of water service is five dollars ($5.00) per month. (Ord. 2004-36,
11-24-2004)
   D.   Sewer Service Maintenance Fee: The sewer service maintenance fee shall
be five dollars ($5.00) per month for all residential and commercial users
effective as of June 1, 2019, and one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) per month
for all industrial users effective as of August 1, 2019.
   E.   Annual Increase: All industrial water and sewer rates are subject to an
annual increase of four percent (4%) per year, with the first increase
occurring on January 1, 2021. (Ord. 2019-15, 5-9-2019)
   F.   Terms: For all purposes of this chapter, the terms "meter", "metered"
and "metered rate" shall refer to the water meter installed unless the Village
has given prior approval of installation of a sewer meter. (Ord. 2019-09, 4-10-
2019)
8-1-9: BILLS RENDERED; DUE DATE:
   A.   Bills for water supply and sewer service shall be rendered monthly and
are payable to the Village Clerk at the Village office. (Ord. 89-08, 8-2-1989;
amd. 2013 Code)
   B.   Bills for water or sewerage service shall be payable at the Office of
the Village Clerk within twenty (20) days after commencement of the next
billing period, and in the event said bills are not paid within that time, the
Village reserves the right to suspend water or sewer service for all unpaid
current water or sewer bills and charges, to remain suspended until payment is
made. (Ord. 85-04, 5-7-1985)
   C.   Any bill unpaid within twenty (20) days after commencement of the next
billing period shall incur a delinquency fee of twenty dollars ($20.00) in
addition to any other penalties or charges imposed.
   D.   Any account for which a check is issued for payment, and the check
issued to the Village is returned for nonsufficient funds, shall incur a charge
of twenty five dollars ($25.00) for each returned check. (Ord. 2014-12, 5-14-
2014)
8-1-10: LIABILITY OF OWNER AND CONSUMER FOR BILLS AND SERVICE:
   A.   Generally: A copy of the Village water and sewer regulations, properly
certified by the Village Clerk, shall be filed in the Office of the County
Recorder of Deeds and shall be deemed notice to all owners of real estate of
their liability for water or sewer service supplied to any occupant or user of
such services upon their properties. (Ord. 85-04, 5-7-1985; amd. 2013 Code)
   B.   Rental Properties:
      1.   Each owner of rental property, whether residential, commercial, or
other, shall be responsible for payment of all water and sewer bills or other
charges when issued, consistent with the procedures established by the Village
in conjunction with collection of said amounts. Nothing in this subsection
shall prohibit the owner of said property from subsequently seeking appropriate
reimbursement from the occupant or occupants of said property.
      2.   Each owner of rental property shall be subject to all remedies
available to the village for nonpayment, including, but not limited to,
termination of service. The village shall not be prohibited from termination of
service for an entire parcel of real estate for: a) partial payment of charges
due by the property owner; or b) for complete payment of charges covering only
a portion of the real estate in question. (Ord. 98-01, 1-7-1998)
8-1-11: REFUNDS AND DISCOUNTS:
No refund or discount on water charges or bills shall be made on account of the
premises served having been vacant or no water used, unless the water service
has been shut off by the village upon written request of the consumer or owner
of the premises, as herein provided. (Ord. 85-04, 5-7-1985)
8-1-12: DELINQUENT BILLS; NOTICE OF JUDGMENT AND LIEN CLAIM:
   A.   Whenever a bill for water or sewer service remains unpaid twenty (20)
days after the commencement of the next billing period, the village clerk shall
file with the recorder of deeds of LaSalle County, a statement of judgment,
then lien claim, which shall contain the legal description of the premises
served, the amount of the unpaid bill, and a notice that the village claims a
lien for this amount as well as for all charges for water and sewer service
subsequent to the period covered by the bill.
   B.   If the consumer of water or sewer service whose bill is unpaid is not
the owner of the premises, and the village clerk has notice of this, notice
shall be mailed to the owner of the premises if his address be known, whenever
such bill remains unpaid for a period of twenty (20) days after the
commencement of the next billing period. (Ord. 85-04, 5-7-1985)
8-1-13: LIEN PROVISIONS:
   A.   Rates And Charges A Lien: All water and sewer charges, rates, and bills
shall be a lien upon the premises and real estate upon or for which the same is
used and supplied, as is provided for by the statutes of the state. (Ord. 85-
04, 5-7-1985)
   B.   Foreclosure Of Lien; Other Remedies: Property subject to a lien for
unpaid water or sewerage charges may be sold for nonpayment of the same, and
the proceeds thereof applied on such charges, after deducting costs, including
reasonable attorney fees, as is the case in foreclosure of statutory liens.
Such foreclosure shall be by bill in equity, in the name of the village. In the
alternative, the village may pursue a concurrent remedy at law to recover the
monies due for services rendered, plus a reasonable attorney fee. (Ord. 95-01,
1-11-1995)
   C.   Suits For Foreclosure: The village legal counsel is hereby authorized
and directed to institute such proceedings, whether in law or equity, in the
name of the village, in any court having jurisdiction over such matters,
against any property or owner thereof for which the water or sewer bill remains
unpaid twenty (20) days after the commencement of the next billing period.
(Ord. 95-01, 1-11-1995; amd. 2013 Code)
8-1-14: DISCONTINUANCE OF SERVICE PROCEDURE:
   A.   Notice Of Delinquency; Options:
      1.   If user's billed charges of water and/or sewer service are not paid
within fifteen (15) days after such billed charges become due, the village
shall provide written notice of delinquency/termination to the user, which
shall state the amount of the delinquency and the date of commencement of the
delinquency (the due date). In addition, such notice shall inform the user of
the following options:
         a.   Immediate payment of the delinquency; or
         b.   Written agreement, within fifteen (15) days, to pay the balance
of the delinquency within one year, in regular monthly installments.
      2.   The notice of delinquency/termination will inform the user that
service will be terminated unless one of the two (2) options set out in
subsection A1 of this section is exercised.
   B.   Interest Penalty: Unless payment is made or a written agreement is
signed within fifteen (15) days of receipt of the notice of delinquency, an
interest penalty of five percent (5%) per annum shall be assessed against the
user's delinquency, applicable to the delinquency period commencing on the due
date.
   C.   Agreement For Installment Payments:
      1.   In order to elect to repay the delinquency over the course of one
year, the user shall enter into a promissory note with the village, whereby the
user shall agree to make the aforesaid monthly installments which shall be
added to the regular monthly charge assessed against the user. If the user
violates the terms of the promissory note, such user's water or sewer service
shall be discontinued without further notice, and shall not be reinstated until
all past due bills are paid in full, including interest, and together with the
cost and charges for the reinstatement of such service.
      2.   Notwithstanding anything herein to the contrary, the village retains
the discretion to allow a payment agreement to extend beyond one year if
circumstances warrant as determined by the village president. The village
president is authorized to designate his authority hereunder to the water/sewer
liaison/chair as determined by the village president.
   D.   Reconnection Of Service; Fee: If a user's service is disconnected
pursuant to this section, there shall be a reconnection fee of one hundred
dollars ($100.00). such payment, as well as such delinquency and interest
associated therewith, shall be paid to the village clerk, or such other person
(s) assigned for the purpose of receiving such funds, by cash or certified
check prior to reinstating water or sewer service. If the reconnection is
requested to occur outside of regular business hours of the Utica Public Works
Department, then the reconnection fee shall be two hundred dollars ($200.00).
(Ord. 2010-17, 6-9-2010; amd. Ord. 2020-18, 8-13-2020)
8-1-15: DISPOSITION OF REVENUES:
The village treasurer shall receive all revenues from the waterworks and
sewerage system and all other funds and monies incident to the operation of
said systems as the same may be delivered to him. Said funds shall be deposited
in separate funds, and the revenue derived from the operation of the sewerage
system shall be deposited in funds as provided for by ordinance relating to the
issuance of revenue bonds for the sewerage system, as said ordinance is now and
may hereafter be amended. (Ord. 85-04, 5-7-1985)
8-1-16: ACCOUNTING:
The village treasurer shall establish a proper system of accounts and shall
keep proper books, records and accounts in which complete and correct entries
shall be made of all transactions relative to the waterworks and sewerage
system, and at regular intervals, annually or more often, the village board of
trustees shall cause to be made an audit of the books by an independent
auditing concern, to show the receipts and disbursements of the water and
sewerage systems. (Ord. 85-04, 5-7-1985)
8-1-17: OFFICE:
The office of the water and sewer department for the transaction of business
shall be located at the village clerk's office, and all monies due the
department from any consumers and users and for all purposes and sources,
including service charges, etc., shall be paid to the village clerk. (Ord. 85-
04, 5-7-1985)
CHAPTER 2
WATER USE AND SERVICE
SECTION:

8-2-10: Authority Of Village To Shut Off Water
8-2-11: Temporary Service

8-2-13: Damage To, Tampering With System
8-2-14: Nonliability Of Village
8-2-15: Discontinuance Of Service
8-2-16: Right Of Entry
8-2-1: CONTRACT FOR SERVICE:
The following rules and regulations, as herein set forth, or as they may be
hereafter amended, shall be considered a part of the contract with every
consumer or user taking water service of the village, and each shall be
considered as having expressed his agreement to be bound thereby. (Ord. 85-04,
5-7-1985)
8-2-2: USE OF PUBLIC SYSTEM REQUIRED:
The owner of all houses, buildings, or other properties used for human
occupancy, employment, recreation, or other purposes situated within the
village and abutting on any street, alley, or right of way in which there is
now located, or may in the future be located, public water service is hereby
required, at his expense, to connect such facilities directly with the proper
public water service in accordance with the provisions of this chapter, within
ninety (90) days after the date of official notice to do so; provided, that
said public water service is within two hundred fifty feet (250') of the
property line; and further provided, that a property within a newly platted
subdivision shall comply with the requirements of subsection 11-6B-7A2a of this
code. (Ord. 89-08, 8-2-1989; amd. 2013 Code)
8-2-3: CONNECTION TO SYSTEM; WATER TAPS:
   A.   1. Applications for water service connections shall be made in writing
to the village clerk by the owners of the property to be served, or the agent
of said owner, which shall state the official street and number to be served,
the size of the pipe required, and approximate location where such a service
shall enter the premises. Thereafter, taps or connections will be made only by
the water and sewerage department at the costs set out in subsection 8-1-8A of
this title. (Ord. 2003-57, 12-10-2003; amd. 2013 Code)
      2.   Charges specified in any existing or future annexation or
preannexation agreements may differ.
   B.   All tap-on fees shall be paid to the village clerk before a tap is
made.
   C.   If a larger tap or connection than one inch (1") in size is desired, or
special services are rendered by the village relative to the tap-on service,
such extra work will be done at the actual cost of labor and materials, plus a
ten percent (10%) charge for overhead expenses. (Ord. 2003-57, 12-10-2003)
8-2-4: PERMIT FOR ADDITIONAL WORK:
After service connection has been made, no person shall make any attachments,
alterations, or connections to said connection to serve other premises, unless
a written permit is first obtained from the village clerk specifying exact work
to be done, said work to be performed according to said permit, ordinances of
the village, and rules and regulations of the water and sewerage department.
(Ord. 85-04, 5-7-1985)
8-2-5: INSTALLATION AND MAINTENANCE OF SERVICE PIPES:
   A.   Installation Of Pipes: No service pipes shall be conducted across lots
or buildings and adjoining premises, but must be laid on streets, alleys, or
public grounds to premises served, and there shall be a separate service pipe
laid at right angles from the main to each premises to be served, and in all
cases, each building served must have an independent service shut off. Where no
water main is available for direct connection, a small temporary main will be
permitted as hereinafter provided. If there are two (2) or more services on the
premises, piping must be separate and no connections made from one to the
other. In buildings containing more than one residential unit, there shall be
an independent service shutoff for each such unit for the purpose of shutting
off service to consumers with delinquent accounts. The water and sewerage
department shall have sole access to these independent shutoffs.
   B.   Curb Box And Valves:
      1.   A curb stop box or shutoff shall be placed on every pipe at right
angles to the main and shall be no more than twelve inches (12") outside of the
sidewalk line on the street side and no more than twelve inches (12") outside
of the lot line on alley side, and the cover of the same shall be at the same
height as the sidewalk or surrounding ground. (Ord. 85-04, 5-7-1985)
      2.   Every service pipe must also have a stop and waste valve placed in
the building within nine inches (9") of the point where the pipe enters the
building, and it shall be kept in such condition that water may be shut off at
any time by the occupants of the premises. There shall also be a gate valve
placed inside of the premises.
   C.   Pipe Specifications: All service lines replaced or installed henceforth
must be at least three-fourths inch (3/4") in diameter, and must be installed a
minimum depth of four and one- half feet (41/2'). Service lines must have a
minimum working pressure rating of one hundred sixty (160) psi at seventy three
and four-tenths degrees Fahrenheit (73.4°F) and must be constructed of one of
the following types of materials: copper (type K), polyvinyl chloride (PVC),
polyethylene, or polybutylene. Service lines must not be covered until they are
inspected and approved by a duly authorized village representative.
   D.   Responsibility For Installation And Maintenance Of Pipes: All service
pipes and fixtures from the main to the premises shall be installed and
maintained at the expense of the owner or owners of the premises. If any leaks
or other defects in the same come to the knowledge of the water and sewerage
department, such department shall notify the owner or owners of the premises,
who shall promptly repair said leak or other defect, and if such repairs are
not effected, water will be turned off and remain turned off until such repairs
are made and expense thereof charged against said owner or owners, to be paid
before water will be turned on again. Any person, firm or corporation violating
this section shall be fined as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code for each offense. (Ord. 85-04, 5-7-1985; amd. 2013 Code)
8-2-6: WATER METERS:
Water meters and related pipe connections may be located near the curb box, or
within the user's premises as determined by the village representative. The
meter must be located at a point where it is readily accessible. The water user
shall permit the meter to be located upon his property and shall allow such
access as is necessary for purposes of construction, repair, maintenance, meter
reading, relocation or expansion of the water system, including such meters, as
may be necessary. (Ord. 85-04, 5-7-1985; amd. Ord. 2001-05, 3-7-2001; 2013
Code)
8-2-7: HEATING EQUIPMENT OR DEVICES:
All consumers hereafter installing equipment or devices for heating water for
domestic use through the plumbing system shall install a suitable automatic
relief valve and check valve so arranged that in event of overheating of water,
there can be no reversal overflow, all on the cold water inlet side of the
heating equipment or devices. (Ord. 85-04, 5-7-1985)
8-2-8: APPLICATION FOR WATER SERVICE:
   A.   Application For Service: Application for water service shall be made in
writing to the village clerk on the blanks furnished by the clerk, stating the
street and number to be served, which said application shall be made at least
seven (7) days in advance of the time service is required.
   B.   Change Of Residence:
      1.   No consumer or user of water services, when a change of residence
occurs, shall be given water service at the new residence until all delinquent
water bills and charges owing from the furnishing of water services at a prior
place of residence or business shall be paid. (Ord. 85-04, 5-7-1985)
      2.   No water service at such new location shall be turned on, and if
turned on, it shall be turned off until a charge of twenty five dollars
($25.00) shall be paid for turning on the water and renewing the service. (Ord.
99-25, 12-8-1999)
   C.   Satisfying Outstanding Bills Required: No water service shall be
established at any location until all prior bills and charges incurred by a
prior consumer at said location have been paid in full. (Ord. 85-04, 5-7-1985)
8-2-9: WATER SERVICE RATES:
The rates for water service for all users are established in section
8-1-8 of this title. (Ord. 2001-05, 3-7-2001)
8-2-10: AUTHORITY OF VILLAGE TO SHUT OFF WATER:
   A.   Whenever it becomes necessary, the village may, without notice, shut
off water service for purposes of making repairs or extensions, or for other
purposes, and no claim shall be made against the village by reason of the
breakage of any service pipe or service cock, or from other damage resulting
therefrom.
   B.   The water and sewerage department shall give notice of shutting off of
water if conditions are such that it is possible to do so.
   C.   When water is shut off, consumers of water service on premises which
have water heaters or heat coils shall turn off the water at the basement
shutoff and open a faucet in the hot water pipe and leave it open until water
is again turned on, in order to protect piping and fixtures from excessive
pressure from hot water or steam. (Ord. 85-04, 5-7-1985)
8-2-11: TEMPORARY SERVICE:
Application shall be made to the village clerk for any temporary service
desired by contractors, builders, or other users for water to be used in
construction work, or for any other purpose. The charge for such water service
shall be four dollars ($4.00) per one thousand (1,000) gallons of water used,
with a four dollar ($4.00) minimum charge. (Ord. 85-04, 5-7-1985)
8-2-12: UNLAWFUL USE, UNNECESSARY WASTE OF WATER:
   A.   Unlawful Use Prohibited: No consumer shall supply water to other
persons, nor allow them to take water, unless special permission is received
from the village, and if such permission is granted, the consumer shall be held
responsible for the payment for the water supply. (Ord. 85-04, 5-7-1985; amd.
2013 Code)
   B.   Unnecessary Waste Prohibited: Consumers shall prevent the unnecessary
waste of water and shall keep all water outlets closed when not in actual use.
Should unnecessary waste occur, village reserves the right to cut off the water
supply. The village further reserves the right to prohibit the use of water for
yard sprinklers, etc., and all large users of water whenever the village shall
deem it necessary to do so. (Ord. 85-04, 5-7-1985)
8-2-13: DAMAGE TO, TAMPERING WITH SYSTEM:
   A.   No user, either person, firm or corporation, shall tamper, adjust,
damage or in any manner interfere with the components or operation of the water
system owned by the village.
   B.   The shutoff valve shall be opened only by a duly authorized
representative of the village. (Ord. 85-04, 5-7-1985)
   C.   Penalty for tampering, damaging, adjusting, or in any manner
interfering with the components or operation of the system shall be as provided
in section
1-4-1 of this code for each such offense. If said penalty is not paid within
thirty (30) days after the amount is determined, the village shall shut off the
water service. In addition to said penalty, the user, person, firm or
corporation responsible shall reimburse the village for the actual cost of
repairing any damage arising from the act. Users shall report any known
evidence of tampering, adjusting, damaging, or interference with operation of
the system, owned by the village, to the board of trustees. Any malicious act
or damage to the system shall be prosecuted through a court of law. (Ord. 85-
04, 5-7-1985; amd. 2013 Code)
8-2-14: NONLIABILITY OF VILLAGE:
   A.   The village shall not be held responsible by reason of the breaking of
any service pipe or apparatus, water coil, or for failure in the supply of
water.
   B.   The village shall not be responsible for any damage that may occur by
reason of improper fixtures, or improper connections, or for any other causes
when turning on water.
   C.   The village does not guarantee that the supply of water will at all
times be constant, nor does the village agree to furnish water at all times,
and it will not be liable to any consumer for any damage in failing to maintain
a continuing or even supply of water. (Ord. 85-04, 5-7-1985)
8-2-15: DISCONTINUANCE OF SERVICE:
   A.   Notice Required: Consumers who wish to discontinue the use of water
service shall give notice in writing to the village clerk who shall then cause
said water service to be turned off, at which time all water bills and charges
shall immediately become due and payable. Water bills and charges shall
continue until said notice is given.
   B.   Reconnection Fee: When water service is again desired after such
discontinuance, a charge of one hundred dollars ($100.00) shall be made and
collected before turning on water service. If the reconnection is requested to
occur outside of regular business hours of the Utica Public Works Department,
then the reconnection fee shall be two hundred dollars ($200.00). (Ord. 85-04,
5-7-1985; amd. Ord. 99-25, 12-8-1999; Ord. 2020-18, 8-13-2020)
8-2-16: RIGHT OF ENTRY:
The superintendent of public works or employees of the village shall be
permitted at all reasonable hours to enter the premises or building of
consumers of water services for the purpose of examining water pipes and
fixtures and the manner in which the water is used. (Ord. 85-04, 5-7-1985; amd.
2013 Code)
ARTICLE A. CROSS CONNECTION CONTROL
SECTION:
8-2A-1: Purpose
8-2A-2: Definitions
8-2A-3: Compliance With Existing Laws
8-2A-4: Cross Connections Restricted
8-2A-5: Surveys, Investigations, Tests
8-2A-6: Backflow Prevention Devices
8-2A-7: Booster Pumps
8-2A-8: Approval Of Corrections And Protective Devices
8-2A-9: Piping Identification
8-2A-10: Private Water Storage Tanks
8-2A-11: Elimination Of Existing Cross Connections
8-2A-12: Inspections
8-2A-13: Violations; Discontinuance Of Water Service
8-2A-14: Penalty
8-2A-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this article is:
   A.   To protect the public water supply system from contamination of
pollution by isolating within the customer's water system contaminants or
pollutants which could backflow through the service connection into the public
water supply system.
   B.   To promote the elimination or control of existing cross connections,
actual or potential, between the public or consumer's potable water system and
nonpotable water systems, plumbing fixtures and sources or systems containing
substances of unknown or questionable safety.
   C.   To provide for the maintenance of a continuing program of cross
connection control which will prevent the contamination or pollution of the
public and consumer's potable water systems. (Ord. 99-15, 10-13-1999)
8-2A-2: DEFINITIONS:
AGENCY: The Illinois environmental protection agency.
APPROVED: Backflow prevention devices or methods approved by the Research
Foundation For Cross Connection Control of the University Of Southern
California, Association Of State Sanitary Engineers, American Water Works
Association, American National Standards Institute or certified by the National
Sanitation Foundation.
AUXILIARY WATER SYSTEM: Any water source or system on or available to the
premises other than the public water supply system and includes the water
supplied by the system. These auxiliary waters may include water from another
purveyor's public water supply system; or water from a source such as wells,
lakes, or streams; or process fluids; or used water. These waters may be
polluted or contaminated or objectionable or constitute a water source or
system over which the water purveyor does not have control.
BACKFLOW: The flow of water or other liquids, mixtures, or substances into the
distribution pipes of a potable water system from any source other than the
intended source of the potable water supply.
BACKFLOW PREVENTION DEVICE: Any device, method, or type of construction
intended to prevent backflow into a potable water system. All devices used for
backflow prevention in Illinois must meet the standards of the Illinois
plumbing code and the Illinois environmental protection agency.
CONSUMER OR CUSTOMER: The owner, official custodian or person in control of any
premises supplied by or in any manner connected to a public water system.
CONSUMER'S WATER SYSTEM: Any water system located on the customer's premises. A
building plumbing system is considered to be a customer's water system.
CONTAMINATION: An impairment of the quality of the water by the entrance of any
substance to a degree which could create a health hazard.
CROSS CONNECTION: Any physical connection or arrangement between two (2)
otherwise separate piping systems, one of which contains potable water and the
other a substance of unknown or questionable safety or quality, whereby there
may be a flow from one system into the other.
   Direct Cross Connection: A cross connection formed when a water system is
physically joined to a source of unknown or unsafe substance.
   Indirect Cross Connection: A cross connection through which an unknown
substance can be forced, drawn by vacuum or otherwise introduced into a safe,
potable water system.
DOUBLE CHECK VALVE ASSEMBLY: An assembly composed of single, independently
acting check valves approved under ASE standard 1015. A double check valve
assembly must include tight shutoff valves located at each end of the assembly
and suitable connections for testing the watertightness of each check valve.
HEALTH HAZARD: Any condition, device or practice in a water system or its
operation resulting from a real or potential danger to the health and well
being of consumers. The word "severe", as used to qualify "health hazard",
means a hazard to the health of the user that could be expected to result in
death or significant reduction in the quality of life.
INSPECTION: A plumbing inspection to examine carefully and critically all
materials, fixtures, piping and appurtenances, appliances and installations of
a plumbing system for compliance with requirements of the Illinois plumbing
code, 77 Illinois administrative code 890.
NONPOTABLE WATER: Water not safe for drinking, personal, or culinary use as
determined by the requirements of Illinois law.
PLUMBING: The actual installation, repair, maintenance, alteration or extension
of a plumbing system by any person. Plumbing includes all piping, fixtures,
appurtenances and appliances for a supply of water for all purposes, including,
without limitation, lawn sprinkler systems, from the source of a private water
supply on the premises or from the main in the street, alley or at the curb to,
within and about any building or buildings where a person or persons live, work
or assemble. Plumbing includes all piping, from discharge of pumping units, to
and including pressure tanks in water supply systems. Plumbing includes all
piping, fixtures, appurtenances, and appliances for a building drain and a
sanitary drainage and related ventilation system of any building or buildings
where a person or persons live, work, or assemble from the point of connection
of such building drain to the building sewer or private sewage disposal system
five feet (5') beyond the foundation walls.
POLLUTION: The presence of any foreign substance (organic, inorganic,
radiological, or biological) in water that tends to degrade its quality so as
to constitute a hazard or impair the usefulness of the water.
POTABLE WATER: Water which meets the requirements of Illinois law for drinking,
culinary, and domestic purposes.
POTENTIAL CROSS CONNECTION: A fixture or appurtenance with threaded hose
connection, tapered spout, or other connection which would facilitate extension
of the water supply line beyond its legal termination point.
PROCESS FLUID(S): Any fluid or solution which may be chemically, biologically
or otherwise contaminated or polluted in a form or concentration such as would
constitute a health, pollution, or system hazard if introduced into the public
or a consumer's potable water system. This includes, but is not limited to:
   A.   Polluted or contaminated waters.
   B.   Process waters.
   C.   Used waters originating from the public water supply system which may
have deteriorated in sanitary quality.
   D.   Cooling waters.
   E.   Questionable or contaminated natural waters taken from wells, lakes,
streams, or irrigation systems.
   F.   Chemicals in solution or suspension.
   G.   Oils, gases, acids, alkalis and other liquid and gaseous fluids used in
industrial or other processes, or for firefighting purposes.
PUBLIC WATER SUPPLY: All mains, pipes and structures through which water is
obtained and distributed to the public, including wells and well structures,
intakes and cribs, pumping stations, treatment plants, reservoirs, storage
tanks and appurtenances, collectively or severally, actually used or intended
for use for the purpose of furnishing water for drinking or general domestic
use and which serve at least fifteen (15) service connections or which
regularly serve at least twenty five (25) persons at least sixty (60) days per
year. A public water supply is either a "community water supply" or a
"noncommunity water supply".
REDUCED PRESSURE PRINCIPLE BACKFLOW PREVENTION DEVICE: A device containing a
minimum of two (2) independently acting check valves, together with an
automatically operated pressure differential relief valve located between the
two (2) check valves and approved under ASSE standard 1013. During normal flow
and at the cessation of normal flow, the pressure between these two (2) checks
shall be less than the supply pressure. In case of leakage of either check
valve, the differential relief valve, by discharging to the atmosphere, shall
operate to maintain the pressure between the check valves at less than the
supply pressure. The unit must include tightly closing shutoff valves located
at each end of the device, and each device shall be fitted with properly
located test cocks.
SAFE AIR GAP: The minimum distance of a water inlet or opening above the
maximum high water level or overflow rim in a fixture, device or container to
which public water is furnished which shall be at least two (2) times the
inside diameter of the water inlet pipe; but shall not be less than one inch
(1") and need not be more than twelve inches (12").
SECONDARY WATER SUPPLY: A water supply system maintained in addition to a
public water supply, including, but not limited to, water systems from ground
or surface sources or water from a public water supply which in any way has
been treated, processed or exposed to any possible contaminant or stored in
other than an approved storage facility.
SERVICE CONNECTION: The opening, including all fittings and appurtenances, at
the water main through which water is supplied to the user.
SUBMERGED INLET: A water pipe or extension thereto from a public water supply
terminating in a tank, vessel, fixture or appliance which may contain water of
questionable quality, waste or other contaminant and which is unprotected
against backflow.
SURVEY: The collection of information pertaining to a customer's piping system
regarding the location of all connections to the public water supply system and
must include the location, type and most recent inspection and testing date of
all cross connection control devices and methods located within that customer's
pipe system. The survey must be in written form and should not be an actual
plumbing inspection.
SYSTEM HAZARD: A condition through which an aesthetically objectionable or
degrading material not dangerous to health may enter the public water supply
system or a consumer's potable water system.
USED WATER: Any water supplied by a public water supply system to a consumer's
water system after it has passed through the service connection and is no
longer under the control of the water supply official custodian.
WATER PURVEYOR: The owner or official custodian of a public water system.
WATER SYSTEM: Shall be considered as made up of two (2) parts: the public water
supply system and the consumer's water system.
   A.   Public Water Supply System:
      1.   The public water supply system shall consist of the source
facilities and the distribution system, and shall include all those facilities
of the potable water system under the control of the superintendent of public
works up to the point where the consumer's water system begins.
      2.   The source shall include all components of the facilities utilized
in the production, treatment, storage, and delivery of water to the public
water supply distribution system.
      3.   The public water supply distribution system shall include the
network of conduits used to deliver water from the source to the consumer's
water system.
   B.   Consumer's Water System: The consumer's water system shall include all
parts of the facilities beyond the service connection used to convey water from
the public water supply distribution system to points of use.
WATER UTILITY: The village of North Utica water and sewerage department. (Ord.
99-15, 10-13-1999; amd. 2013 Code)
8-2A-3: COMPLIANCE WITH EXISTING LAWS:
All plumbing installed within the village shall be installed in accordance with
the Illinois plumbing code, 77 Illinois administrative code 890. If, in
accordance with the Illinois plumbing code or the judgment of the
superintendent of public works, an approved backflow prevention device is
necessary for the safety of the public water supply system, the superintendent
of public works shall give notice to the water customer to install such an
approved device immediately. The water customer shall, at the customer's
expense, install such an approved device at a location and in a manner in
accordance with the Illinois plumbing code and all applicable local
regulations, and shall have inspections and tests made of such approved devices
upon installation and as required by the Illinois plumbing code and local
regulations. (Ord. 99-15, 10-13-1999)
8-2A-4: CROSS CONNECTIONS RESTRICTED:
   A.   No person, firm or corporation shall establish or permit to be
established or maintain or permit to be maintained any connection whereby a
private, auxiliary or emergency water supply, other than the regular public
water supply of the village, enters the supply or distribution system of the
village, unless such private, auxiliary or emergency water supply and the
method of connection and use of such supply shall have been approved by the
superintendent of public works and the Illinois environmental protection
agency.
   B.   Connections between potable water systems and other systems or
equipment containing water or other substances of unknown or questionable
quality are prohibited, except when and where approved cross connection control
devices or methods are installed, tested and maintained to ensure proper
operation on a continuing basis.
   C.   No physical connection shall be permitted between the potable portion
of a supply and any other water supply not of equal or better bacteriological
and chemical quality as determined by inspection and analysis by the agency.
   D.   There shall be no arrangement or connection by which an unsafe
substance may enter a supply. (Ord. 99-15, 10-13-1999)
8-2A-5: SURVEYS, INVESTIGATIONS, TESTS:
   A.   It shall be the duty of the superintendent of public works to cause
surveys and investigations to be made of industrial and other properties served
by the public water supply to determine whether actual or potential hazards to
the public water supply may exist. Such surveys and investigations shall be
made a matter of public record and shall be repeated at least every two (2)
years, or as often as the superintendent of public works shall deem necessary.
Records of such surveys shall be maintained and available for review for a
period of at least five (5) years.
   B.   The consumer's premises shall be open at all reasonable times to the
approved cross connection control device inspector for the inspection of the
presence or absence of cross connections within the consumer's premises, and
testing, repair and maintenance of cross connection control devices within the
consumer's premises.
   C.   On request by the superintendent of public works, or the
superintendent's authorized representative, the consumer shall furnish
information regarding the piping system or systems or water use within the
customer's premises. The consumer's premises shall be open at all reasonable
times to the superintendent of public works for the verification of information
submitted by the consumer to the public water supply custodian regarding cross
connection inspection results.
   D.   It shall be the responsibility of the water consumer to arrange
periodic surveys of water use practices on the consumer's premises to determine
whether there are actual or potential cross connections to the consumer's water
system through which contaminants or pollutants could backflow into the
consumer's or the public potable water system. All cross connection control or
other plumbing inspections must be conducted in accordance with 225 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 320/3(1).
   E.   It is the responsibility of the water consumer to prevent backflow into
the public water system by ensuring that:
      1.   All cross connections are removed or approved cross connection
control devices are installed for control of backflow and back siphonage.
      2.   Cross connection control devices shall be installed in accordance
with the manufacturer's instructions.
      3.   Cross connection control devices shall be inspected at the time of
installation and at least annually by a person approved by the agency as a
cross connection control device inspector (CCCDI). The inspection of mechanical
devices shall include physical testing in accordance with the manufacturer's
instructions.
   F.   1. Each device shall be tested at the time of installation and at least
annually or more frequency if recommended by the manufacturer. (Ord. 99-15, 10-
13-1999)
      2.   Records submitted to the village shall be available for inspection
by agency personnel in accordance with 415 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/4.
(Ord. 99-15, 10-13-1999; amd. 2013 Code)
      3.   Each device shall have a tag attached listing the date of the most
recent test, name of CCCDI, and type and date of repairs.
      4.   A maintenance log shall be maintained and include:
         a.   Date of each test;
         b.   Name and approval number of person performing the test;
         c.   Test results;
         d.   Repairs or servicing required;
         e.   Repairs and date completed; and
         f.   Service performed and date completed. (Ord. 99-15, 10-13-1999)
8-2A-6: BACKFLOW PREVENTION DEVICES:
   A.   Devices Required:
      1.   An approved backflow prevention device shall be installed on all
connections to the public water supply as described in the plumbing code, 77
Illinois administrative code 890, and the agency's regulations, 35 Illinois
administrative code 680. In addition, an approved backflow prevention device
shall be installed on each service line to a consumer's water system serving
premises, where, in the judgment of the superintendent of public works, actual
or potential hazards to the public water supply system exist.
      2.   An approved backflow prevention device shall be installed on each
service line to a consumer's water system serving premises where the following
conditions exist:
         a.   Premises having an auxiliary water supply, unless such auxiliary
supply is accepted as an additional source by the superintendent of public
works, and the source is approved by the Illinois environmental protection
agency.
         b.   Premises on which any substance is handled which can create an
actual or potential hazard to the public water supply system. This shall
include premises having sources or systems containing process fluids or waters
originating from the public water supply system which are no longer under the
sanitary control of the superintendent of public works.
         c.   Premises having internal cross connections that, in the judgment
of the superintendent of public works and the cross connection control device
inspector, are not correctable or are intricate plumbing arrangements which
make it impractical to determine whether or not cross connections exist.
         d.   Premises where, because of security requirements or other
prohibitions or restrictions, it is impossible or impractical to make a
complete cross connection survey.
         e.   Premises having a repeated history of cross connections being
established or reestablished.
      3.   An approved backflow device shall be installed on all connections to
the public water supply as described in the plumbing code, 77 Illinois
administrative code 890, and the agency's regulations, 35 Illinois
administrative code 653. In addition, an approved backflow prevention device
shall be installed on each service line to a consumer's water system serving,
but not necessarily limited to, the following types of facilities unless the
superintendent of public works determines that no actual or potential hazard to
the public water supply system exists:
         a.   Hospitals, mortuaries, clinics, nursing homes.
         b.   Laboratories.
         c.   Piers, docks, waterfront facilities.
         d.   Sewage treatment plants, sewage pumping stations or stormwater
pumping stations.
         e.   Food or beverage processing plants.
         f.   Chemical plants.
         g.   Metal plating industries.
         h.   Petroleum processing or storage plants.
         i.   Radioactive material processing plants or nuclear reactors.
         j.   Car washes.
         k.   Pesticide, or herbicide, or extermination plants and trucks.
         l.   Farm service and fertilizer plants and trucks.
   B.   Types Of Devices:
      1.   The type of protection required under subsections A1, A2 and A3 of
this section shall depend on the degree of hazard which exists, as follows:
         a.   An approved fixed proper air gap separation shall be installed
where the public water supply system may be contaminated with substances that
could cause a severe health hazard.
         b.   An approved fixed proper air gap separation or an approved
reduced pressure principle backflow prevention device shall be installed where
the public water supply system may be contaminated with a substance that could
cause a system or health hazard.
         c.   An approved fixed proper air gap separation or an approved
reduced pressure principle backflow prevention device shall be installed where
the public water supply system may be polluted with substances that could cause
a pollution hazard not dangerous to health.
      2.   The type of protection required under subsection B1 of this section
shall be an approved fixed proper air gap separation or an approved reduced
pressure principle backflow prevention device.
      3.   Where a public water supply or an auxiliary water supply is used for
a fire protection system, reduced pressure principle backflow preventers shall
be installed on fire safety systems connected to the public water supply when:
         a.   The fire safety system contains antifreeze, fire retardant or
other chemicals;
         b.   Water is pumped into the system from another source;
         c.   Water flows by gravity from a nonpotable source;
         d.   Water can be pumped into the fire safety system from any other
source; or
         e.   There is a connection whereby another source can be connected to
the sprinkler system.
   C.   Approved Devices: All backflow prevention devices or methods required
by this article shall be approved by the Research Foundation For Cross
Connection Control of the University Of Southern California, American Water
Works Association, American Society Of Sanitary Engineering, or American
National Standards Institute or certified by the National Sanitation Foundation
to be in compliance with applicable industry specifications.
   D.   Installation: Installation of approved devices shall be made in
accordance with 35 Illinois administrative code 653.802, and only as specified
by the Research Foundation For Cross Connection Control of the University Of
Southern California or applicable industry specifications. Maintenance, as
recommended by the manufacturer of the device, shall be performed.
Manufacturer's maintenance manual shall be available on site. (Ord. 99-15, 10-
13-1999)
8-2A-7: BOOSTER PUMPS:
   A.   Where a booster pump has been installed on the service line to or
within any premises, such pump shall be equipped with a low pressure cutoff
device designed to shut off the booster pump when the pressure in the service
line on the suction side of the pump drops to twenty (20) psi or less.
   B.   It shall be the duty of the water consumer to maintain the low pressure
cutoff device in proper working order and to certify to the superintendent of
public works, at least once a year, that the device is operable. (Ord. 99-15,
10-13-1999)
8-2A-8: APPROVAL OF CORRECTIONS AND PROTECTIVE DEVICES:
Any user of the water supply system shall obtain written approval from the
water and sewerage department of any proposed corrective action or protective
device before using or installing it. The total time allowed for completion of
the necessary corrections shall be contingent upon the degree of hazard
involved and include the time required to obtain and install equipment. If the
cross connection has not been removed within the time as hereafter specified,
the village shall physically separate the water supply system from the on site
piping system in such manner that the two (2) systems cannot be connected by
any unauthorized person. (Ord. 99-15, 10-13-1999; amd. 2013 Code)
8-2A-9: PIPING IDENTIFICATION:
When a secondary water source is used in addition to the public water supply,
the public water supply and secondary water piping shall be identified as
distinguishing colors or tags and so maintained that each pipe may be traced
readily in its entirety. It will be necessary to protect the water supply
system at the service connection in a manner acceptable to the water and
sewerage department. (Ord. 99-15, 10-13-1999; amd. 2013 Code)
8-2A-10: PRIVATE WATER STORAGE TANKS:
A private water storage tank supplied from the water supply system shall be
deemed a secondary water supply unless it is designed and approved for potable
water usage. (Ord. 99-15, 10-13-1999)
8-2A-11: ELIMINATION OF EXISTING CROSS CONNECTIONS:
Within one year from the effective date hereof, all existing cross connections
to the water supply systems shall be eliminated. The expenses of such
elimination shall be that of the owner of the property on which such cross
connection exists. (Ord. 99-15, 10-13-1999)
8-2A-12: INSPECTIONS:
The approved cross connection control device inspector shall have the right to
enter at any reasonable time any property served by a connection to the public
water supply or distribution system of the village for the purpose of verifying
the presence or absence of cross connections, and the superintendent of public
works or the superintendent's authorized agent shall have the right to enter at
any reasonable time any property served by a connection to the public water
supply or distribution system of the village for the purpose of verifying
information submitted by the customer regarding the required cross connection
control inspection. On demand, the owner, lessees or occupants of any property
so served shall furnish to the superintendent of public works any information
which the superintendent may request regarding the piping system or systems or
water use on such property. The refusal of such information, when demanded,
shall, with the discretion of the superintendent of public works, be deemed
evidence of the presence of improper connections as provided in this article.
(Ord. 99-15, 10-13-1999)
8-2A-13: VIOLATIONS; DISCONTINUANCE OF WATER SERVICE:
   A.   The superintendent of public works is hereby authorized and directed to
discontinue, after reasonable notice to the occupant thereof, the water service
to any property wherein any connection in violation of the provisions of this
article is known to exist, and to take such other precautionary measures as the
superintendent may deem necessary to eliminate any danger of contamination of
the public water supply distribution mains. Water service to such property
shall not be restored until such conditions have been eliminated or corrected
in compliance with the provisions of this article, and until a reconnection fee
of five hundred dollars ($500.00) is paid to the village. Immediate
disconnection with verbal notice can be effected when the superintendent of
public works is assured that imminent danger of harmful contamination of the
public water supply system exists. Such action shall be followed by written
notification of the cause of disconnection. Immediate disconnection without
notice to any party can be effected to prevent actual or anticipated
contamination or pollution of the public water supply; provided, that in the
reasonable opinion of the superintendent of public works or the Illinois
environmental protection agency, such action is required to prevent actual or
potential contamination or pollution of the public water supply. Neither the
village nor the superintendent of public works, or any agents or assigns
thereof, shall be liable to any customer for any injury, damages or lost
revenues which may result from termination of said customer's water supply in
accordance with the terms of this article, whether or not said termination was
with or without notice. (Ord. 99-15, 10-13-1999; amd. 2013 Code)
   B.   Water service to such premises shall not be restored until the consumer
has corrected or eliminated such conditions or defects in conformance with this
article and to the satisfaction of the superintendent of public works, and the
required connection fee is paid. (Ord. 99-15, 10-13-1999)
8-2A-14: PENALTY:
The consumer responsible for back siphoned material or contamination through
backflow, if contamination of the potable water supply system occurs through an
illegal cross connection or an improperly installed, maintained or repaired
device, or a device which has been bypassed, must bear the cost of cleanup of
the potable water supply system. The village may issue a monetary penalty for
noncompliance in accordance with the provisions of this code. (Ord. 99-15, 10-
13-1999)
ARTICLE B. WATER MAIN EXTENSIONS
SECTION:
8-2B-1: Definitions
8-2B-2: Contractor Requirements
8-2B-3: Permit For Connection; Fee And Bond
8-2B-4: Application For Connection Or Extension
8-2B-5: Plans
8-2B-6: Specifications
8-2B-7: Notice Of Excavation
8-2B-8: Protection Of Work
8-2B-9: Separate Connections Required
8-2B-10: Inspections; Costs
8-2B-11: Responsibility For Costs
8-2B-12: Installation Of Service; Costs
8-2B-13: Responsibility For Maintenance Of Service
8-2B-14: Existing Unauthorized Connections
8-2B-15: Damage To, Trespassing Upon System
8-2B-16: Enforcement
8-2B-17: Violations; Penalty
8-2B-1: DEFINITIONS:
Unless the context indicates otherwise, the meanings of terms used in this
article shall be as follows:
PERSON: Any individual, firm, corporation, association, or other entity.
VILLAGE: The village of North Utica, LaSalle County, Illinois, acting by and
through its duly constituted mayor and village board of trustees, or other duly
authorized representative or representatives.
WATER MAIN: Any pipe connected to the village water system shown on the
official village water main map.
WATER SERVICE: Any water line connected to a village water main and serving a
single water customer. (Ord. 77-04, 9-6-1977; amd. 2013 Code)
8-2B-2: CONTRACTOR REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   License And Bond Required: No person shall make any main or service
connection to the village water system until he has applied for and obtained
from the village clerk a license to extend the water system and has posted a
surety bond with the village clerk that has been approved by the village board
of trustees in the amount of five hundred dollars ($500.00) or ten percent
(10%) of the estimated cost, whichever is greater. Said bond shall be
conditioned upon the applicant's faithful prosecution of such waterworks as he
may undertake in strict compliance with the provisions of this article. (Ord.
77-04, 9-6-1977; amd. 2013 Code)
   B.   Qualifications; License Fee: The applicant shall present evidence that
he is competent to perform water extensions, and shall pay a license fee of
twenty five dollars ($25.00) annually for the issuance or renewal of such
"license to extend water system".
   C.   Liability For Work: Each and every contractor or subcontractor will be
liable for his own work and any work which he may have subcontracted. (Ord. 77-
04, 9-6-1977)
8-2B-3: PERMIT FOR CONNECTION; FEE AND BOND:
   A.   No person shall make or cause to be made any main or service connection
to any water main in the village until he has applied for and received a permit
for such connection from the mayor, and then only in the manner and at the
location described in the permit. The fee for such permit shall be three
dollars ($3.00).
   B.   No work shall begin without written permission from the mayor, and no
work shall begin until a performance bond is posted with the village. Each
contractor or subcontractor will be required to post a bond in the amount of
five hundred dollars ($500.00) or ten percent (10%) of the estimated cost,
whichever is greater. (Ord. 77-04, 9-6-1977; amd. 2013 Code)
8-2B-4: APPLICATION FOR CONNECTION OR EXTENSION:
The form of permit for water main or service connection described in section
8-2B-3 of this article shall also include an application for water service to
be signed by the owner of the premises where such connection is to be made
before said permit is issued. Said application shall cause the owner and/or
lessee of the premises to be liable and subject to the charges for water
service provided for by the village board of trustees. (Ord. 77-04, 9-6-1977)
8-2B-5: PLANS:
   A.   Main Extension: Prior to any main extension, the developer, at his
expense, shall obtain a permit from the state environmental protection agency
or current applicable agency. The permit application shall be approved and
signed by the village upon completion of the work, and an as built set of plans
shall be filed with the village clerk.
   B.   Service Extension: A sketch showing the as built location of the
service and appurtenances shall be filed with the village clerk. (Ord. 77-04,
9-6-1977)
8-2B-6: SPECIFICATIONS:
All work shall be in accordance with the "State Of Illinois Standard
Specifications For Water And Sewer Main Construction", adopted July 1973, or
latest revision thereof. (Ord. 77-04, 9-6-1977)
8-2B-7: NOTICE OF EXCAVATION:
No person shall open or excavate any trench for any purpose whatsoever in any
street, alley or other public grounds in which any water line is laid without
first giving notice to the superintendent of public works of the nature and
location of such intended work and the date and time such work will be
undertaken. (Ord. 77-04, 9-6-1977)
8-2B-8: PROTECTION OF WORK:
The owner of the premises or his agents shall conduct the work of making
service connections or private lines in such a manner as to provide for the
safety of workers, property and the public. He shall provide and maintain
proper barricades, warning lights and other safety precautions usually employed
on such work. (Ord. 77-04, 9-6-1977)
8-2B-9: SEPARATE CONNECTIONS REQUIRED:
Each and every house, business building or institution and industry must have a
direct and separate connection with the main. The connection of two (2) or more
such structures to the public main with one pipe is expressly forbidden. (Ord.
77-04, 9-6-1977)
8-2B-10: INSPECTIONS; COSTS:
   A.   Inspections Required: Inspections will be needed for the following:
      1.   Ditch Excavation: Depth and width.
      2.   Sand Bedding: Processed sand; a minimum of six inches (6") under
pipe; a minimum of twelve inches (12") will be required if rock is encountered.
      3.   Laying Of Pipe: Pipe shall be laid to the specified grade; all
joints shall remain visible until pressure tests are taken.
      4.   Sand Overlay: Depth check; all water mains shall have a minimum of
twelve inches (12") of processed sand placed over the top.
      5.   Locating Tape: Metallic detecting tape shall be placed approximately
eighteen inches (18") below finished ground line over all water main and over
all services.
      6.   Fire Hydrants:
         a.   All hydrants shall be a maximum of four hundred feet (400') from
the farthest point of any property to be serviced unless otherwise shown on the
plans.
         b.   Shutoff valves shall be installed at proper heights, and a
minimum of one cubic yard of one-fourth inch (1/4") to three- eighths inch (3/
8") pea gravel shall be placed on the bottom of the fire hydrants for drainage.
      7.   Shutoffs: Water shutoffs will be placed in accordance with the plans
or as designated by the village.
   B.   Entry Powers: The superintendent of public works or other persons
authorized by the village to inspect service or main connections shall, upon
request, have free and unobstructed access to all parts of any premises where
such services are planned to be made, are being made or have been made during
all daylight hours for the purpose of examining the construction, location,
condition and usage of said service connection. The superintendent of public
works shall be notified by the owner of the premises, or his agent, upon
completion of pipe laying and before backfilling and again upon completion of
backfilling and street repair work for his inspection and approval.
   C.   Violations: Materials and/or workmanship which are disapproved by the
superintendent of public works shall be removed immediately and replaced with
satisfactory materials and workmanship at the expense of the owner or his
agent.
   D.   Responsibility Of Owner For Costs: The owner will pay all expenses to
have the installation of water main extension inspected and certified by a
registered professional engineer. A copy of the engineer's certification as
required by the state shall be deposited with the village clerk. (Ord. 77-04,
9-6-1977)
8-2B-11: RESPONSIBILITY FOR COSTS:
   A.   All costs of the construction and connection, from the point of
connection with the public main designated on the permit to the terminus of the
service connection or private line, shall be borne by the owner of the premises
served, or his agents. He shall also bear the costs of replacing all street
paving, sidewalks, pipelines, utility lines and other public property damaged
or destroyed by him or his agent in constructing the service or water main. He
shall be liable for all damage to persons or property through negligence of
himself or his agents in doing such work, and shall save the village harmless
in any damage suits arising therefrom. (Ord. 77-04, 9-6-1977; amd. 2013 Code)
   B.   All costs of the reconstruction and maintenance of service connections
or private lines from the point of the buffalo box to the terminus of the
service connection or private line shall be borne by the owner of the premises
served, or his agents. He shall also bear the cost of replacing all street
paving, sidewalks, pipelines, utility lines, and other public property damaged
or destroyed by him or his agent in this regard, assuming that property which
is damaged is located between the buffalo box and the terminus of the service
connection or private line. He shall be liable for all damage to persons or
property through negligence of himself or his agents in doing such work, and
shall save the village harmless from any damage suits arising therefrom, as
described in the previous sentence. (Ord. 94-11, 8-3-1994)
8-2B-12: INSTALLATION OF SERVICE; COSTS:
The village will install water service to the property line on the street where
the main is located. Installation charges to the property owner will be charged
at the village's cost of prevailing labor and materials, plus a ten percent
(10%) overhead charge. Permission may be granted by the village for private
installation. (Ord. 77-04, 9-6-1977)
8-2B-13: RESPONSIBILITY FOR MAINTENANCE OF SERVICE:
The property owner is responsible for maintenance of the buffalo box and the
service from the buffalo box into the house. (Ord. 77-04, 9-6-1977)
8-2B-14: EXISTING UNAUTHORIZED CONNECTIONS:
All persons having any existing unauthorized connections with any of the water
mains within the village shall either disconnect such connections immediately
and provide proper connection after receiving a permit for service connection
in the usual manner, or shall take out a permit, notify the superintendent of
public works of the desire for an inspection, and uncover all pipes and
otherwise provide proof that the connection has been made substantially in
accordance with the provisions of this article. (Ord. 77-04, 9-6-1977)
8-2B-15: DAMAGE TO, TRESPASSING UPON SYSTEM:
   A.   Damage To System Prohibited: No person shall wilfully, maliciously or
negligently deface, break, destroy or injure in any manner any water main or
appurtenance, or any part of the water plant. No person shall interfere with,
molest, uncover or disturb any part of any water system, appurtenance thereto,
or any part of the water plant or the grounds, landscaping or fencing of the
disposal plant site, except the employees of the village authorized to do so.
   B.   Trespassing Prohibited: No person, except employees of the village,
shall enter upon the site or grounds of the water plant unless express
permission to do so shall have been obtained from the mayor of the village or
the superintendent of public property. (Ord. 77-04, 9-6-1977)
8-2B-16: ENFORCEMENT:
It is hereby made the duty of the superintendent of public works or his duly
authorized agent to enforce full compliance with the terms of this article in
every particular relating to water main or service connections. (Ord. 77-04, 9-
6-1977)
8-2B-17: VIOLATIONS; PENALTY:
   A.   Misdemeanor Violation; Penalty: Any person who shall be found guilty of
violating any of the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of a
misdemeanor and shall be fined not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor
more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) for the first offense, and for each
subsequent offense, such person shall be fined not less than fifty dollars
($50.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each day on
which any violation of any provision of this article may continue, and each day
shall be deemed a separate offense. (Ord. 77-04, 9-6-1977; amd. 2013 Code)
   B.   Liability For Violation: Any person violating any of the provisions of
this article shall become liable to the village for any expense or damage
occasioned to the village by reason of such violations. (Ord. 77-04, 9-6-1977)
ARTICLE C. WELL DRILLING
SECTION:
8-2C-1: Definitions
8-2C-2: Permit Required
8-2C-3: Application For Permit; Fee
8-2C-4: Advisory Report
8-2C-5: Hearing
8-2C-6: Conditions And Contents Of Permit
8-2C-7: Scope Of Provisions
8-2C-8: Penalties
8-2C-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement of
this article:
HIGH CAPACITY WELL OR WELL SYSTEM: A water well or several water wells equipped
with a pump or pumps which either, individually or working together, are
capable of producing more than ten thousand (10,000) gallons of groundwater in
a twenty four (24) hour period.
RESIDENTIAL OR AGRICULTURAL WELL: A single groundwater supply well which
provides for household drinking, culinary and sanitary purposes and serves not
more than four (4) families or is for agricultural purposes. (Ord. 2009-26, 10-
14-2009)
8-2C-2: PERMIT REQUIRED:
No person, partnership, corporation, governmental body, association or any
other entity shall drill, establish or maintain a high capacity well for any
purpose, other than residential or agricultural wells, as defined in section
8-2C-1 of this article, within the corporate boundaries of the village without
first receiving a permit for said well from the village board of trustees.
(Ord. 2009-26, 10-14-2009)
8-2C-3: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT; FEE:
   A.   Every applicant for a well drilling or maintenance permit for a high
capacity well shall submit to the village clerk a written application
containing the following information:
      1.   The name of the applicant.
      2.   The name of the owner of the property on which the well is to be
located.
      3.   The name of the proposed user of said well.
      4.   The legally described location of said proposed well.
      5.   The purpose for which said well will be drilled, the estimated daily
usage of water to be pumped and the proposed maximum daily capacity of said
well.
      6.   The estimated date upon which well drilling will begin.
      7.   If an existing well is to be upgraded to a high capacity well, the
date on which said modifications will be completed.
      8.   Report of a certified engineer showing that the proposed well
drilling will not cause pollution to, depletion of or injury to the water
source or the water table of the village.
   B.   A nonrefundable application fee in the sum of three hundred fifty
dollars ($350.00) shall be paid for each permit sought. (Ord. 2009-26, 10-14-
2009)
8-2C-4: ADVISORY REPORT:
Within ten (10) days after receiving the application, the village clerk shall
deliver the application to the village engineer. The village engineer may
request from the applicant such additional information as may be deemed
necessary to evaluate the application. Within thirty (30) days after receipt of
all of the information requested from the applicant and of the written report
from the village engineer, the village engineer shall submit to the board of
trustees an advisory report reviewing the probable effect of the proposed well
on the water source of the village. Such report shall be accompanied by the
report from the engineer, the application, and all information received from
the applicant. Such report shall also be accompanied by a recommendation by the
village engineer as to whether the permit requested should be granted. (Ord.
2009-26, 10-14-2009)
8-2C-5: HEARING:
The submission to the village board of trustees of the application, as provided
herein, shall cause a hearing to be held as follows: The board of trustees
shall, in considering the application, consider whether the applicant has
presented satisfactory evidence that the drilling or use of said well will not
cause pollution or injury to or depletion of the water source of the village,
or threaten pollution or injury to or depletion of the water source of the
village, or threaten pollution or injury to or depletion of the water table
underlying the village and the surrounding area covered by this article. (Ord.
2009-26, 10-14-2009)
8-2C-6: CONDITIONS AND CONTENTS OF PERMIT:
The village board of trustees shall not grant a permit for drilling unless the
applicant has presented satisfactory evidence that the drilling or use of said
well shall not cause pollution or injury to or depletion of the water source of
the village, or threaten pollution or injury to or depletion of the water table
underlying the village and the surrounding area covered by this article. The
permit shall state the maximum number of gallons of water that may be pumped
per twenty four (24) hour period in excess of ten thousand (10,000) gallons.
(Ord. 2009-26, 10-14-2009)
8-2C-7: SCOPE OF PROVISIONS:
This article shall apply to every high capacity well sought to be drilled after
the effective date hereof. This article shall apply to every existing well that
is made operational as a high capacity well after the effective date hereof.
(Ord. 2009-26, 10-14-2009)
8-2C-8: PENALTIES:
   A.   Injunction: Upon the failure of any individual to comply with the
provisions of this article, the village may make application to the circuit
court for an injunction requiring conformance with this article or make such
other order as the court deems necessary to secure compliance herewith. (Ord.
2009-26, 10-14-2009)
   B.   Fine: Any person who violates any provision of this article shall, upon
conviction thereof, be fined not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor
more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). A separate offense shall be
deemed committed for each day during or on which the violation occurs or
continues. (Ord. 2009-26, 10-14-2009; amd. 2013 Code)
   C.   Additional Remedies: Nothing herein shall prevent the village from
taking other lawful action to prevent or remedy any violations. All costs
connected therewith shall accrue to the person or persons responsible. (Ord.
2009-26, 10-14-2009)
CHAPTER 3
SEWER USE AND SERVICE
SECTION:
8-3-1: Definitions
8-3-2: Use Of Public Sewers Required
8-3-3: Private Sewage Disposal Systems
8-3-4: Building Sewers And Connections
8-3-5: Discharges Into Public System
8-3-6: Interceptors
8-3-7: Preliminary Treatment; Flow Equalization
8-3-8: Control Manhole
8-3-9: Measurements, Tests And Analyses
8-3-10: Special Agreements
8-3-11: Sewerage Rates
8-3-12: Protection Of System From Damage
8-3-13: Powers And Authority Of Inspectors
8-3-14: Violation; Penalties
8-3-1: DEFINITIONS:
ADMINISTRATOR: The administrator of the U.S. environmental protection agency.
APPROVING AUTHORITY: The superintendent of public works.
BIOCHEMICAL OXYGEN DEMAND (BOD): The quantity of oxygen utilized in the
biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in
five (5) days at twenty degrees centigrade (20°C), expressed in milligrams per
liter (mg/l).
BUILDING DRAIN: That part of the lowest piping of a drainage system which
receives the discharge from soil, waste and other drainage pipes inside the
walls of the building and conveys it to the building sewer or other approved
point of discharge, beginning five feet (5') (1.5 meters) outside the inner
face of the building wall.
BUILDING SEWER: The extension from the building drain to the public sewer or
other place of disposal.
COMBINED SEWER: A sewer which is designed and intended to receive wastewater,
stormwater, surface water and groundwater drainage.
COMMERCIAL USER: As defined in section
8-1-3 of this title.
CONTROL MANHOLE: A structure located on a site from which industrial wastes are
discharged. Where feasible, the manhole shall have an interior drop. The
purpose of a control manhole is to provide access for the village
representative to sample and/or measure discharges.
DIRECTOR: The director of the Illinois environmental protection agency.
EASEMENT: An acquired legal right for the specific use of land owned by others.
EFFLUENT CRITERIA: Are defined in any applicable NPDES permit.
FEDERAL ACT: The federal clean water act (33 USC 466 et seq.), as amended
(Pub.L. 95-217).
FEDERAL GRANT: The U.S. government participation in the financing of the
construction of treatment works as provided by title II grants for construction
of treatment works of the act and implementing regulations.
FLOATABLE OIL: Oil, fat or grease in a physical state such that it will
separate by gravity from wastewater by treatment in an approved pretreatment
facility. A wastewater shall be considered free of floatable oil if it is
properly pretreated and the wastewater does not interfere with the collection
system.
GARBAGE: Solid wastes from the domestic and commercial preparation, cooking and
dispensing of food and from the handling, storage and sale of food.
INDUSTRIAL USERS: As defined in section
8-1-3 of this title.
INDUSTRIAL WASTE: Any solid, liquid or gaseous substance discharged, permitted
to flow or escaping from any industrial, manufacturing, commercial or business
establishment or process or from the development, recovery or processing of any
natural resource as distinct from sanitary sewage.
MAJOR CONTRIBUTING INDUSTRY: An industrial user of the publicly owned treatment
works that:
   A.   Has a flow of fifty thousand (50,000) gallons or more per average
workday; or
   B.   Has a flow greater than ten percent (10%) of the flow carried by the
municipal system receiving the waste; or
   C.   Has in its waste a toxic pollutant in toxic amounts as defined in
standards issued under section 307(a) of the federal act; or
   D.   Is found by the permit issuing authority, in connection with the
issuance of the NPDES permit to the publicly owned treatment works receiving
the waste, to have significant impact, either singly or in combination with
other contributing industries, on that treatment works or upon the quality of
effluent from that treatment works.
MAY: Permissible.
MILLIGRAMS PER LITER: A unit of the concentration of water or wastewater
constituent. It is 0.001 gram of the constituent in one thousand milliliters
(1,000 ml) of water. It has replaced the unit formerly used commonly, parts per
million, to which it is approximately equivalent, in reporting the results of
water and wastewater analysis.
NPDES PERMIT: Any permit or equivalent document or requirements issued by the
administrator, or where appropriated by the director, after enactment of the
federal clean water act to regulate the discharge of pollutants pursuant to
section 402 of the federal act.
NATURAL OUTLET: Any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, lake or other body
of surface water or groundwater.
ppm: Parts per million by weight.
PERSON: Any and all persons, natural or artificial, including any individual,
firm, company, municipal or private corporation, association, society,
institution, enterprise, governmental agency or other entity.
pH: The logarithm (base-10) of the reciprocal of the hydrogen ion concentration
expressed by one of the procedures outlined in the IEPA division of
laboratories manual of laboratory methods.
POPULATION EQUIVALENT: A term used to evaluate the impact of industrial or
other waste on a treatment works or stream. One population equivalent is one
hundred (100) gallons of sewage per day, containing two hundred sixty
milligrams per liter (260 mg/l) of BOD and three hundred milligrams per liter
(300 mg/l) of suspended solids.
PRETREATMENT: The treatment of wastewaters from sources before introduction
into the wastewater treatment works.
PROPERLY SHREDDED GARBAGE: The wastes from the preparation, cooking and
dispensing of foods that have been shredded to such a degree that all particles
will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public
sewers, with no particle greater than one-half inch (1/2") (1.27 centimeters)
in any dimension.
PUBLIC SEWER: A sewer provided by or subject to the jurisdiction of the
village. It shall also include sewers within or outside the village boundaries
that serve one or more persons and ultimately discharge into the village
sanitary system, even though those sewers may not have been constructed with
village funds.
REPLACEMENT: Expenditures for obtaining and installing equipment, accessories
or appurtenances which are necessary during the useful life of the treatment
works to maintain the capacity and performance for which such works were
designed and constructed. The term "operation and maintenance" includes
replacement.
RESIDENTIAL USER: As defined in section
8-1-3 of this title.
SANITARY SEWER: A sewer that conveys sewage or industrial wastes, or a
combination of both, and into which stormwater, surface water and groundwater
or unpolluted industrial wastes are not intentionally admitted.
SEWAGE: Is used interchangeably with "wastewater".
SEWER: A pipe or conduit for conveying sewage or other waste liquids, including
stormwater, surface water and groundwater drainage.
SEWERAGE: The system of sewers and appurtenances for the collection,
transportation and pumping of sewage.
SEWERAGE FUND: The principal accounting designation for all revenues received
in the operation of the sewerage system.
SHALL: Mandatory.
SLUG: Any discharge of water, sewage or industrial waste which, in
concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of flow, exceeds, for any
period of duration longer than fifteen (15) minutes, more than five (5) times
the average twenty four (24) hour concentration of flows during normal
operation.
